         <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n        </div>\r\n            <div class=\"history-entries-wrap         <div class=\"wi-date\">22 December 2015</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n        $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-body js-content-body\">\r\n            <div class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu_split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Anupreeta More, Masamune Oguri, Issha Kayo, Joel Zinn, Michael A. Strauss, Basilio X. Santiago, Ana M. Mosquera, Naohisa Inada, Christopher S. Kochanek, Cristian E. Rusu, Joel R. Brownstein, Luiz N. da Costa, Jean-Paul Kneib, Marcio A. G. Maia, Robert M. Quimby, Donald P. Schneider, Alina Streblyanska, Donald G. York,  The SDSS-III BOSS quasar lens survey: discovery of 13 gravitationally lensed quasars, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 456, Issue 2, 21 February 2016, Pages 1595\u20131606, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv2813\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv2813</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100487 id=\"92100487\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of 13 confirmed two-image quasar lenses from a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in the SDSS-III Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS). We adopted a methodology similar to that used in the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS). In addition to the confirmed lenses, we report 11 quasar pairs with small angular separations ( \u2272 2\u00a0arcsec) confirmed from our spectroscopy, which are either projected pairs, physical binaries, or possibly quasar lens systems whose lens galaxies have not yet been detected. The newly discovered quasar lens system, SDSS J1452+4224 at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 4.8 is one of the highest redshift multiply imaged quasars found to date. Furthermore, we have over 50 good lens candidates yet to be followed up. Owing to the heterogeneous selection of BOSS quasars, the lens sample presented here does not have a well-defined selection function.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100489 id=\"92100489\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitationally lensed quasars provide a unique tool to study the Universe. In particular, the time-variable nature of quasars enable us to measure the arrival time difference between quasar multiple images, which may be a powerful probe of cosmology (e.g. Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Applications of gravitationally lensed quasars such as time delay cosmography (e.g. Coles <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), constraints on the quasar luminosity function (e.g. Comerford, Haiman &amp; Schaye <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Richards et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), constraints on dark energy (e.g. Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and study of the host galaxy and/or black hole properties (e.g. Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Mosquera et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are still limited by small number statistics, indicating the importance of finding new gravitationally lensed quasars in wide-field surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) considerably advanced the field by discovering nearly 50 new quasar lenses. The SQLS was based upon the large sample of spectroscopically confirmed quasars in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey \u2013 I/II (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). Candidates were first selected from the \u223c100\u2009000 spectroscopic quasars and their SDSS images were then examined to identify quasars with extended morphology or with nearby companion objects of similar colour. The lens candidates were then confirmed with various facilities to construct a secure sample of gravitationally lensed quasars. Thanks to the well-studied selection function (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), a subsample of the SQLS quasar lenses was used to place statistical limits on dark energy and the evolution of massive galaxies that act as lenses (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS; Dawson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) of the SDSS-III (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is a new spectroscopic survey to measure the expansion rate of the Universe. In addition to an extensive spectroscopic survey of <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5 galaxies, BOSS has obtained spectra of \u223c300\u2009000 quasars (Alam et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) with over 180\u00a0000 in the redshift range 2.15 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 4 in order to detect baryon acoustic oscillation signatures in the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 absorption features of their spectra. The large number of BOSS quasars suggests that it should contain a large number of gravitationally lensed quasars. However, the lensing rate of the BOSS quasar sample is likely smaller than that of the SDSS-II quasar sample because BOSS largely targets point-like quasar candidates in order to increase the survey efficiency. In this case, lensed quasars where the images are not individually resolved would appear extended and would tend to be excluded by the BOSS selection function. On the other hand, the typical BOSS quasar is at a higher redshift (<em>z</em> \u223c 2\u20133 Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) than the typical SDSS-I/II quasars (<em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20132) and this higher average redshift may partly compensate for the lower lensing rate due to the morphological target selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thus started a new survey for gravitationally lensed quasars from BOSS called the BOSS quasar lens survey (BQLS). The basic strategy follows that of the SQLS in that we select quasar lens candidates by examining the SDSS images of BOSS quasars and conduct additional observations of any promising quasar lens candidates. In this paper, we present 13 confirmed quasar lenses from the BQLS. In addition, we also identify 11 quasar close pairs with not quite identical but similar spectra. Some of these may be true gravitational lenses but could not be confirmed due to lack of detection of a lens galaxy or spectra being slightly different due to effects such as microlensing and dust extinction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we describe the selection of our lens candidates. In Section 3, we describe the additional observations undertaken for a detailed examination of the most promising lens candidates. The mass modelling of the lenses is described in Section 4. We compare the confirmed lenses to the SQLS lens sample and present our general findings in Section 5. Section 6 presents our summary and conclusions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100495 id=\"92100495\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We selected candidate quasar lens systems from the imaging and spectroscopic data of SDSS-III/BOSS. The SDSS uses a dedicated 2.5-metre telescope at Apache Point Observatory in New Mexico (Gunn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The SDSS imaging data uses five (<em>ugriz</em>) broad-band filters and has a limiting magnitude of <em>r</em> \u223c 22.5, which were used to select various targets including quasars for spectroscopic observations (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The SDSS-III/BOSS survey uses an upgraded multi-object fibre spectrograph which can simultaneously take spectra of 1000 objects with a resolving power <em>R</em> \u223c 2000 and a wavelength coverage of 3600 &lt; \u03bb &lt; 10\u2009400\u2009\u00c5 (Smee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We largely followed the procedures established in the SQLS for the lens candidate selection process. In the SQLS, however, there were also image separation and flux ratio limits for constructing a complete lens sample for statistical studies. In SDSS-III, constructing a well-defined statistical sample is much more challenging because of the complex nature of the quasar target selection (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Thus, we first adopted a simple approach of applying the SQLS-like selection criteria and then choosing the best lens candidates by visually inspecting the SDSS images of all of the resulting lens candidates. Below we describe these procedures in more detail.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The selection method for the underlying SDSS-III/BOSS spectroscopic quasar sample is presented in Ross et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Currently all of the BOSS data are public, and the quasar catalogue we used is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org/dr12/algorithms/boss-dr12-quasar-catalog/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss.org/dr12/algorithms/boss-dr12-quasar-catalog/</a>. From the spectroscopic quasar catalogue, we selected quasar lens candidates using a method similar to SQLS, in which morphological and colour criteria were used to select lens candidates from the object catalogue. The full details of the SQLS selection algorithm are presented in Oguri et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and Inada et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). While the SQLS selection criteria were optimized for selecting low-redshift (<em>z</em> &lt; 2.2) quasar lens candidates, an extension of the selection algorithm to higher redshifts is discussed in Inada et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). In this paper, we adopted a modified version of these morphological and colour selection criteria as described below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The morphological selection approach identified spectroscopic quasars that are poorly fit by the imaging point spread function (PSF). Even though BOSS targeted point-like quasars, there are extended objects with a spectroscopic classification of a quasar in BOSS which were originally identified as galaxies and targeted as part of the galaxy follow-up programmes or ancillary programmes targeting AGNs. Therefore, we applied the morphological selection to find small image separation lensed quasars which appear as extended quasar-like sources. Specifically, we used the following object parameters; <span class=\"monospace\">type</span>, which describes the classification of objects as stars (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\tt type}=6$|\u2060</span>) or galaxies (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\tt type}=3$|\u2060</span>); <span class=\"monospace\">lnlStar</span>, which is the logarithm of the likelihood of objects being fitted by the PSF of the field; <span class=\"monospace\">lnlDeV</span>, which is the logarithm of the likelihood of objects being fitted by the de Vaucouleurs profile. The parameters <span class=\"monospace\">lnlStar</span> and <span class=\"monospace\">lnlDeV</span> are available for each broad-band. For quasars at 0.7 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 3, we selected lens candidates whose <em>gri</em>-band object parameters satisfy <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlStar} &lt; -1$|</span> for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt type}=3$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlDeV} &lt; -15$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlStar} - {\\tt lnlDeV} &lt; -5$|</span> for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt type}=6$|\u2060</span>. For quasars at <em>z</em> &gt; 3, we used the same criteria as above but only for the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands. There were \u223c3000 candidates selected by these criteria.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a given spectroscopic quasar, the colour selection method searches for nearby objects with similar colours out to a maximum image separation of \u0394\u03b8 = 30\u00a0arcsec. For quasars at 0.7 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 3.4, we used all five bands and select objects with colour differences smaller than 0.1 for <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> and <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and smaller than 0.2 for <em>u</em> \u2212 <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>, where the colours were computed using PSF magnitudes. For quasars at <em>z</em> &gt; 3.4, we used only the <em>griz</em>-bands and similar thresholds for the colour differences of 0.1 for <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and 0.2 for <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>. We also required that the <em>i</em>-band magnitude difference of the two objects was smaller than 1. When the angular separation of the two objects were small (&lt;3.5\u00a0arcsec), we used relaxed colour criteria as the SDSS photometry might not be reliable (see Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). This colour selection method led to a sample of \u223c2000 candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then visually inspected all the morphological and colour selected lens candidates. The visual inspection was performed by one of the authors (MO) to define \u2018good\u2019 lens candidates that have relatively high chance of being true lens systems. Here, the goodness of the candidates was judged by various factors including the presence of multiple components with quasar-like colours or nearby galaxies that might act as lenses. Most of the false positives removed in the visual inspection are either single quasars with contamination from bright nearby objects and obvious quasar-galaxy superpositions. Large-separation ( \u2273 5\u00a0arcsec) quasar lenses are much less common, and hence large-separation lens candidates are not regarded as good unless putative lens galaxies or clusters are seen in between the candidate quasar images. We finally selected \u223c80 good candidates and an additional \u223c70 possible lens candidates from the morphological selection, and \u223c75 good candidates and \u223c65 possible lens candidates from the colour selection. There is an overlap of \u223c20 good candidates between the morphology and colour selected samples. The number of lens candidates, requiring observational follow-up studies was reduced by a factor of \u223c20 through the visual inspection. This suggests that our approach is an efficient approach to find the most promising lens candidates. Nevertheless, it is possible that we missed some true gravitational lens systems in the course of the visual inspection. For example, we are likely to miss quasars that are fainter and do not visually look star-like which includes some small image-separation lenses and possibly quadruply imaged systems. We may also have missed systems with atypical image configurations, odd colours or highly anomalous flux ratios.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that Dahle et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) discovered a gravitationally lensed sextuple quasar with a maximum image separation of 15.1\u00a0arcsec, SDSS J2222+2745, from the SDSS-III data. They searched for strong lens candidates by visually inspecting photometrically identified clusters of galaxies. Even though this lens system meets our image separation criteria, none of the lensed quasars from SDSS J2222+2745 were selected for spectroscopy by BOSS so this source is not in our parent sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some gravitationally lensed quasars have been discovered by identifying quasar spectral features superposed on the spectra of lens galaxies (e.g. Johnston et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) although this technique of identifying compound objects spectroscopically has primarily discovered many examples of lensed star-forming galaxies (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>). As a complementary approach to the SQLS selection technique, we also searched for lensed quasars using this technique. We identified instances of quasar-galaxy superpositions in the BOSS spectra with quasars at <em>z</em> &lt; 5.5 and galaxies with redshifts lower than the quasars (Zinn et\u00a0al., in preparation). The initial sample had 17 good candidates out of which three systems were followed-up spectroscopically as part of the BQLS sample. Currently, this search has produced \u223c100 candidates with a \u2018good\u2019 visual quality flag and will be presented in Zinn et\u00a0al. (in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The BOSS DR12 catalogue has some known lenses, several of which are in the SQLS. This known sample was excluded prior to the visual inspection of the candidates. In total, we identified about 250 new lens candidates for further study. In the next section, we present initial follow-up results of the most promising quasar lens candidates.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100505 id=\"92100505\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>DATA: OBSERVATION, REDUCTION AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our follow-up observations consist of imaging and spectroscopic observations. We first attempt to obtain follow-up images for the good lens candidates, and conduct follow-up spectroscopic observations only when the follow-up images show evidence for gravitational lensing. However, it was not possible to follow this strategy strictly due to observing constraints. In some cases, we obtained follow-up spectra before we conducted imaging follow-up observations. Among these systems, those with clear differences in the spectra were thus not observed with imaging. Since the spectroscopic observations are very informative for confirming or ruling out the lensing hypotheses of the candidates, below we first present the complete spectroscopic follow-up results for the best 55 candidates, and then present imaging follow-up results for confirmed gravitational lens systems. The full imaging follow-up results will be presented in an upcoming paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100507 id=\"92100507\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>Spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> summarizes our spectroscopic observations. We obtained spectra of five candidates with the Low Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (LRIS; Oke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) on the Keck telescope on 2013 September 7. We used the 1.0\u00a0arcsec slit, the 400/3400 grism for the blue channel and the 400/8500 grating for the red channel. The spectral resolution was <em>R</em> \u223c 600 in the blue channel and <em>R</em> \u223c 1300 in the red channel. The red channel was binned to give 0.27\u2009arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The unbinned blue channel has 0.135\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. We also obtained spectra of 50 candidates with the Faint Object Camera and Spectrograph (FOCAS; Kashikawa et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) on the Subaru telescope on 2014 May 2, 2015 Feb 19, and 2015 June 19. In all of the FOCAS observations we used the 1.0\u00a0arcsec slit, but adopted two different configurations depending on the quasar redshifts; one is the grism and filter set of 300B/L600 to cover the wavelength range of 3700\u20136000 \u00c5, and the other is 300B/SY47 4700\u20139100 \u00c5. Both data sets have a spectral resolution of <em>R</em> \u223c 400\u2013500. The data were binned 2 \u00d7 2 on the detector, providing a spatial resolution of 0.21\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. In all of the observations, the long-slit was aligned to observe both putative quasar images simultaneously. The data were reduced using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> tasks.</p>                        <a id=\"92100509\" scrollto-destination=\"92100509\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of spectroscopic observations. The \u2018Selection\u2019 column indicates the method(s) with \u2018M\u2019 for morphological selection, \u2018C\u2019 for colour selection, and \u2018S\u2019 for spectroscopic selection (see the text for details). Several candidates were selected by multiple methods. \u2018Observation\u2019 indicates the telescope (S-Subaru or K-Keck), the date and setup of the spectroscopic observations (see also Section 3.1). \u2018Result\u2019 indicates the conclusion from the follow-up spectroscopy as well as imaging observations described in Section 3.2. The <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> are taken from the BOSS DR12 catalogue which has redshifts corrected after visual inspection of the spectra. The last column has redshifts from the follow-up spectra except when marked with<sup><em>a</em></sup> which are taken from the BOSS spectrum.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. J2314\u22120108\u00a0</td><td>23:14:24.50\u00a0</td><td>\u221201:08:58.7\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>3.455\u00a0</td><td>S, 2015 Feb (300B/SY47)\u00a0</td><td>1080\u00a0</td><td>Different SED\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100509\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We found that 13 out of the 55 quasar lens candidates contain two quasar components with identical redshifts and similarities in the spectral energy distributions (SEDs). Together with the analysis of the imaging observations presented below, we conclude that these 13 systems are gravitationally lensed quasars. Our spectroscopy also identified an additional 11 quasar pairs with either almost identical or slightly different redshifts. Properties of these 11 quasar pairs will be discussed in Sections 3.3 and 5.3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> presents the spectra for the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including the 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars. For five of the quasar lens systems, the lens galaxies are bright enough to be clearly detected in one of the quasar spectra. We successfully measured the lens redshift for these lens systems (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). For an additional three quasar systems, the lens galaxies are bright and their redshifts were derived from the SDSS-III spectra. The subsequent spectra do not cover the red wavelength range where these lens galaxies can be detected easily.</p>                        <a id=\"92100512\" scrollto-destination=\"92100512\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=ShFhVBb739wh6wn-DVTi~pe7Zr6yrnnWLm~SNm2t6CxcdYJv~cMUp1e2nJ7gyg8v1cm7s5KgNMxssmlQafMvjwwyutrwazYaogACJOtmHGEQG6kw8mMyl1YfmD42RQo5MHCeU~~fPdcF5FmU3Wjb87JBrjfS5xxMNJrPdiALN9~OF~oMl2pqq9RNwwx5WwjzdCfTTobwFuvci1taVx8M4BBVT1I6J52SVne8MFwwTsVNeoz7ThkL5fcq~Frm5UmbgzahyxIxxJF77ri6OT-jBYN1MvTKUod12Gx4ne7kEBBnv2AEFn6KpAKYt-BW~Q38v-P3u9Xn2WaHHnxOQKMIjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table 1). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux F\u03bb is in units of 10\u221217erg\u2009cm\u22122\u2009s\u22121\u2009\u00c5 \u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100512/stv2813fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100512\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=tedkoQPBc~RyMrRVPNM1oRHbXslVhA-7BZ5bsBMeV8eoxX8B-C4FLLaCgfqyTSy3L0qNk0Wj2~tOb~PRelSOHzx5vP6cMDIVO6sSGKiziDfyXUHepE5dTOTYrurJBPMRwMvktDr6GRGmp5pf04YDblwhq3dZxpy9MBHpEVuCVKIUIgidyyTH2cFAkOU226BSKUDv58IzEWcMo5wM3CohXOgPbd2TYWCgaKUkt2pUeJfEMqjAISaUM21XV9vbZU6B0m4lyzC4U4codUlVG78q5p5psxopewjbIP3TvuyqOYYNX3PzTh7-T464QpBJiifo1tH9Fnci7~IWvbMyh54OAw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100512&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux <em>F</em><sub>\u03bb</sub> is in units of 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009\u00c5 <sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=ShFhVBb739wh6wn-DVTi~pe7Zr6yrnnWLm~SNm2t6CxcdYJv~cMUp1e2nJ7gyg8v1cm7s5KgNMxssmlQafMvjwwyutrwazYaogACJOtmHGEQG6kw8mMyl1YfmD42RQo5MHCeU~~fPdcF5FmU3Wjb87JBrjfS5xxMNJrPdiALN9~OF~oMl2pqq9RNwwx5WwjzdCfTTobwFuvci1taVx8M4BBVT1I6J52SVne8MFwwTsVNeoz7ThkL5fcq~Frm5UmbgzahyxIxxJF77ri6OT-jBYN1MvTKUod12Gx4ne7kEBBnv2AEFn6KpAKYt-BW~Q38v-P3u9Xn2WaHHnxOQKMIjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table 1). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux F\u03bb is in units of 10\u221217erg\u2009cm\u22122\u2009s\u22121\u2009\u00c5 \u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100512/stv2813fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100512\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=tedkoQPBc~RyMrRVPNM1oRHbXslVhA-7BZ5bsBMeV8eoxX8B-C4FLLaCgfqyTSy3L0qNk0Wj2~tOb~PRelSOHzx5vP6cMDIVO6sSGKiziDfyXUHepE5dTOTYrurJBPMRwMvktDr6GRGmp5pf04YDblwhq3dZxpy9MBHpEVuCVKIUIgidyyTH2cFAkOU226BSKUDv58IzEWcMo5wM3CohXOgPbd2TYWCgaKUkt2pUeJfEMqjAISaUM21XV9vbZU6B0m4lyzC4U4codUlVG78q5p5psxopewjbIP3TvuyqOYYNX3PzTh7-T464QpBJiifo1tH9Fnci7~IWvbMyh54OAw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100512&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux <em>F</em><sub>\u03bb</sub> is in units of 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009\u00c5 <sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100513 id=\"92100513\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>Imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We imaged a subsample of the most promising candidates in two to three bands with the goal of detecting the lens galaxy. At minimum, these imaging data should better resolve the small separation lensed quasar images to provide the basic constraints required for mass modelling. The majority of the lenses from the BQLS sample were observed with the Tektronix 2048\u00d72048 CCD camera (Tek2k, with a pixel resolution of 0.22\u00a0arcsec) on the UH88 telescope. A few of the candidates were observed with other telescopes. A summary of these observations is given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> which includes the exposure times for each filter. We used the FOCAS instrument with 2 \u00d7 2 binning on Subaru giving a pixel resolution of 0.208\u00a0arcsec, the SOI instrument (pixel resolution of 0.15\u00a0arcsec) on the SOuthern Astrophysical Research (SOAR) telescope and the OSMOS instrument (pixel resolution of 0.273\u00a0arcsec) on the Hiltner telescope of the MDM observatory. We processed the data in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> by following standard procedures. The seeing of our imaging data is better than 1\u00a0arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"92100515\" scrollto-destination=\"92100515\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0821+4542\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>2160 (<em>V</em>) 1980 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0921+2854\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2015 Feb 20\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V</em>) 1080 (<em>I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>3060 (<em>V</em>) 2880 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V</em>) 2160 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2015 Feb 20\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>OSMOS\u00a0</td><td>2013 Apr 08\u00a0</td><td>1200 (<em>g</em>) 2100 (<em>r</em>) 900 (<em>i,z</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>FOCAS\u00a0</td><td>2015 Jun 19\u00a0</td><td>270 (<em>R</em>) 360 (<em>I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>SOI\u00a0</td><td>2013 Feb 12\u00a0</td><td>420 (<em>g,r,i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V</em>) 1800 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2012 Sep 17\u00a0</td><td>960 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em> Tek2k is on the UH88 telescope, OSMOS is on the Hiltner telescope, FOCAS is on the Subaru telescope and SOI is at the SOAR telescope.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100515\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In most cases, the imaging reveals two point-like components with a hint of extended emission close to one of those components indicating presence of a lens galaxy. We use <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to model each of these components and to measure their fluxes and positions. The quasars are assumed to be point sources convolved with the PSF and the galaxy is modelled with a S\u00e9rsic profile. The use of point sources for the quasar components is reasonable because all the quasars are at high redshifts <em>z</em> &gt; 1. We use the nearby stars as a model for the PSF. We first fit models to the two quasars without the lens. Next, we fit models including the lens. Both modelling results are compared and the latter model is accepted if the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> and the residuals have improved. In the cases when it was difficult to fit the S\u00e9rsic index of the galaxy's light profile, we held it fixed at <em>n</em> = 4, since the de Vaucouleurs profile (de Vaucouleurs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1948</a>) is a good model for early-type galaxies. The modelling results for all of the 13 confirmed lenses are presented in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. For each lens, we show the reddest available image (left-hand panel) where the contribution from the lens galaxy is easier to see than in the other bands, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model which includes the lens galaxy (second panel from left) and the residuals from this model (third panel from left). For comparison, we also show the residuals from the model without the lens galaxy in the right-most panel.</p>                        <a id=\"92100517\" scrollto-destination=\"92100517\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=OQrNIi6oraYN2E8mRAjbqcVVUBChn6rQtJvZfkckOwutaXQYEmQhizWQW4h6QsIxRf8sGL3~329PxBBJ4~57QlRymo5BsA4i2~BvQIJejjyMbPPyyOld2q-Wr8Q34ivolKV~JdD0nS8g2pWF2ctVUy5YQu0kg2xVdauSXupX-DI92IdgN2-ZCOpZWMu76uP6irTfxdZWcVZ~QrT7t-KO4DV42fkuubbvARL6gv03V2YHJAnoI0xiSjhQJjZ0TKz-g8UKYMKcqkMqiKiC7TGX22Nwe0PoBgKk84t12T212LorfIqI17SwzhN9m1uIAM4MaExuD~xbPvMsMCvJM6qwzw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the galfit model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100517/stv2813fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=ElG1wBWd-ahW6cA8EjQN9G97ctXiK7Uh9ZMh50usgmjhzrKqry0RxqCBy~zXpZ4y9sQaO8tzEz60qyfdZrcVOne8DqPeMDlBqzd2fzH7GVCotrxk-wgloYMeRwqUvkPfVFKXsCc6baz8zBvu9Wv6V78b9WG38gOYYaR7witHBsyfbPaKwZk7w1uBcBPBRu6Vgmgn3WehWBSr2ZHSHz1lANqyM-9jin2oMv~lEljk8TRdl4sd5u4WZQqoQvwbJGPs4L3mdv3EsugZdvsHUTawNUEwCS5TfzbyX4BQFA8bM8hd5WwfWPWndtKWDIDIe2qGa84lrcCvlxFPoiWnOW86ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100517&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=OQrNIi6oraYN2E8mRAjbqcVVUBChn6rQtJvZfkckOwutaXQYEmQhizWQW4h6QsIxRf8sGL3~329PxBBJ4~57QlRymo5BsA4i2~BvQIJejjyMbPPyyOld2q-Wr8Q34ivolKV~JdD0nS8g2pWF2ctVUy5YQu0kg2xVdauSXupX-DI92IdgN2-ZCOpZWMu76uP6irTfxdZWcVZ~QrT7t-KO4DV42fkuubbvARL6gv03V2YHJAnoI0xiSjhQJjZ0TKz-g8UKYMKcqkMqiKiC7TGX22Nwe0PoBgKk84t12T212LorfIqI17SwzhN9m1uIAM4MaExuD~xbPvMsMCvJM6qwzw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the galfit model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100517/stv2813fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=ElG1wBWd-ahW6cA8EjQN9G97ctXiK7Uh9ZMh50usgmjhzrKqry0RxqCBy~zXpZ4y9sQaO8tzEz60qyfdZrcVOne8DqPeMDlBqzd2fzH7GVCotrxk-wgloYMeRwqUvkPfVFKXsCc6baz8zBvu9Wv6V78b9WG38gOYYaR7witHBsyfbPaKwZk7w1uBcBPBRu6Vgmgn3WehWBSr2ZHSHz1lANqyM-9jin2oMv~lEljk8TRdl4sd5u4WZQqoQvwbJGPs4L3mdv3EsugZdvsHUTawNUEwCS5TfzbyX4BQFA8bM8hd5WwfWPWndtKWDIDIe2qGa84lrcCvlxFPoiWnOW86ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100517&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We performed relative photometry of the lenses by comparing them to nearby stars with known SDSS magnitudes. First, we used the software from Astrometry.net (Lang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to determine the orientations of the images and the positions of the stars, except for SDSS J1458\u22120202 and SDSS J1452+4224 where the astrometry was determined manually. For every lens in every band available from the imaging, we measured the fluxes of about a dozen stars using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). The zero-points were determined by comparing the SDSS magnitudes to the fluxes of the stars. Owing to the differences between the SDSS filters and those used for the follow up observations, we had to apply appropriate filter conversions to the fluxes. We adopted the conversions from Jester et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and Lupton (2005, unpublished) which are available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.sdss3.org/dr8/algorithms/sdssUBVRITransform.php\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.sdss3.org/dr8/algorithms/sdssUBVRITransform.php</a>. The zero-points were then used for determining the magnitudes of the lensed quasars and lens galaxies. The results of the relative astrometry and photometry are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The best-fitting parameters of the S\u00e9rsic model assumed for the lens galaxies are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92100519\" scrollto-destination=\"92100519\"></a>\r\n<div 5.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>0.38 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>e</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" 1.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>2.13 \u00b1 0.24\u00a0</td><td>3.81 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td><td>0.36 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>30.6 \u00b1 1.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>3.57 \u00b1 2.09\u00a0</td><td>5.90 \u00b1 1.92\u00a0</td><td>0.37 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>87.2 \u00b1 graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100520\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">S\u00e9rsic parameters of the lens galaxies. The parameters <em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, <em>n</em>, <em>e</em>, and \u03b8<sub>e</sub> denote the effective radius, S\u00e9rsic index, ellipticity, and the position angle (measured counter-clockwise from north where north is up at 0\u00b0), respectively. See Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> for the magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n 9.7\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>0.61 \u00b1 0.15\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>0.58 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>15.5 \u00b1 7.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>0.99 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td><td>4.19 \u00b1 0.70\u00a0</td><td>0.21 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>68.2 \u00b1 6.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>1.09 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>0.30 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>\u221223.8 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>2.13 \u00b1 0.24\u00a0</td><td>3.81 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td><td>0.36 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>30.6 \u00b1 1.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>3.57 \u00b1 2.09\u00a0</td><td>5.90 \u00b1 1.92\u00a0</td><td>0.37 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>87.2 \u00b1 5.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>0.38 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100520\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100521 id=\"92100521\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>Notes on interesting individual systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss the properties of some of the interesting systems from the BQLS.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100523 id=\"92100523\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-1>SDSS J0818+0601</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectrum shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> indicates that the two stellar components separated by \u0394\u03b8 \u223c 1\u00a0arcsec have similar spectra (\u0394<em>V</em> = 226\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), including broad absorption features in the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines. However, no lens galaxy was found in our SOAR images (420\u00a0s in <em>i</em>). If this is a gravitational lens, the non-detection of the lens suggests it is at a relatively high redshift (<em>z<sub>l</sub></em> \u2273 1).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100525 id=\"92100525\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-2>SDSS J0821+0735</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the spectra of the components (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) indicate that the quasar redshifts are almost same (\u0394<em>V</em> = 319\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), their SEDs appear to be slightly different. The emission line features have different profiles and the continuum shows differences in the slope. Some differences in the SEDs of lensed counterparts can be attributed to dust extinction in the lens galaxy (e.g. Falco et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) or microlensing. However, the UH88 imaging observation (1440\u00a0s in <em>I</em>) also failed to detect any lens between the quasar components.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100527 id=\"92100527\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-3>SDSS J0921+2854</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After we confirmed the lensing nature of this object, an archival search revealed that this lens was independently discovered by E. Ofek et\u00a0al., and was observed by the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> Cycle 20 programme GO-13001 although their results are unpublished. There are also X-ray and radio detections for this system, probably emanating from the lensed quasar.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100529 id=\"92100529\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-4>SDSS J0930+4614</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a quasar pair at the same redshift (\u0394<em>V</em> = 111\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) but with quite different SEDs (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The fainter component has broad absorption lines associated with Ly\u00a0\u03b1, Si\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines, while the brighter component has no broad absorption features. Given the markedly different SEDs, this is likely to be a physical quasar pair rather than a lens.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100531 id=\"92100531\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-5>SDSS J1043+4320</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a quasar pair with similar redshifts (\u0394<em>V</em> = 1778\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>). There are strong absorption lines in the C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines of both components, but the overall SED shapes appear to be different (see Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). It is important to conduct a deep imaging to search for a possible lens galaxy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100533 id=\"92100533\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-6>SDSS J1124+5710</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SEDs of this quasar pair appear similar but have slightly different redshifts (\u0394<em>V</em> = 496\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). There is no indication of a lens galaxy in our UH88 imaging (1440\u00a0s in <em>I</em>). Hence, we conclude that this is likely a binary quasar system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100535 id=\"92100535\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-7>SDSS J1309+5617</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the redshifts of the two components are almost identical (\u0394<em>V</em> = 169\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the significantly different shapes of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines mean that this system is likely to be a binary quasar system rather than a lens.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100537 id=\"92100537\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-8>SDSS J1405+1350</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SED of the fainter quasar has some similarity with the SED of the brighter quasar but the emission features have very low signal-to-noise ratios. The redshifts are not identical but imply that the quasars are probably physically associated (\u0394<em>V</em> = 1400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>). Additionally, the non-detection of a putative lens galaxy suggests this might be a binary quasar system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100539 id=\"92100539\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-9>SDSS J1452+4224</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> \u2248 4.8,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> the quasar redshift of this lens is one of the highest redshifts known and is comparable to the lens SDSS J0946+1835 (McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The total lensing magnification is predicted to be \u223c8 by our mass models in Section 4. The lens galaxy is quite visible in the spectrum and the image, and has one of the lowest measured lens redshift (<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.382) in our sample. Coincidentally, the lens galaxy of SDSS J0946+1835 is at a similar redshift but more massive given the wider image separations of the lensed quasars.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100541 id=\"92100541\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-10>SDSS J2146\u22120047</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the lensing nature of this object was confirmed by our imaging and spectroscopic follow-up observations, Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>) recently reported an independent discovery of this lens using Dark Energy Survey data. They tentatively assigned a lens redshift of <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.799 based on Mg\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and Fe\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption features in the quasar spectra. The absorption feature is also seen in the Subaru spectrum shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100543 id=\"92100543\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>MASS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We created mass models for the 13 spectroscopically confirmed lens systems with the modelling software, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The redshifts of the quasars and the lens galaxies were taken from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. For those systems with no lens redshifts, we adopted a fiducial value of <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.5 (\u223cpeak of the redshift distribution of typical lenses e.g. see Fig <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), as a lens redshift is required in the estimate of the velocity dispersion.</p>                        <a id=\"92100545\" scrollto-destination=\"92100545\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=QTO5I8V4qL2mEhJHOhqTz1e9lyf7InjHhJ32pnEGUzzEizZsdBAS6OWdgu4--ZQn4Tw1r2clsspk6k-E7Tq578wxaxgE5IsO3jfJQj09g2xnWB0gKHzU0OzLqdeSvp8eYzIFxsaa2SleIrdo4z9ldDSQXhhM-TIydp-sJJfT5AKKl~F6cQJRiq6FGeQb2S8hjafmMb5BEE9x-nEWzvT30YKllZ8nvFZt1WYtWBBB0k-M75l6H~lSyyt4e2dcizl3ZxG01uu3tnkKMdyr5LcxLnwIZaOqzUR1TBaTI5UgsU49uFlNvlghVmFywMNzkSZjS3bhDwv158phyYZulEeIbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100545/stv2813fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100545\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=YCBSrx17RLt7ZAYUUcjx1qvVpfz5-AzzD1gsHf0ttGET5QlHShGrRc0Q591Uue~NC60XkVjJqxF8zkwb~P1hpDvH6Bj6Vbnu4Pd5BbbmIAYiX5ftDH~Y44fZ3K~0cYzy9M2UQXaju0E1OSjJhuUv0Rke~SrpFOEWz00P37xXjmgRcQ602VgkuMY5iMli3pwqT79dwZJ6I2arE~5usYpszTLFfavUO7EhUO-oxuv-893DITqbms7OLq2-cjCcuuroTt7vBmwgENXNUMIPg52wZdGyF2enT9bVDlpwT4cfdXrssiCj72PddiuXa5WPx7Enz3R-lajtab-osPurynIrUQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100545&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=QTO5I8V4qL2mEhJHOhqTz1e9lyf7InjHhJ32pnEGUzzEizZsdBAS6OWdgu4--ZQn4Tw1r2clsspk6k-E7Tq578wxaxgE5IsO3jfJQj09g2xnWB0gKHzU0OzLqdeSvp8eYzIFxsaa2SleIrdo4z9ldDSQXhhM-TIydp-sJJfT5AKKl~F6cQJRiq6FGeQb2S8hjafmMb5BEE9x-nEWzvT30YKllZ8nvFZt1WYtWBBB0k-M75l6H~lSyyt4e2dcizl3ZxG01uu3tnkKMdyr5LcxLnwIZaOqzUR1TBaTI5UgsU49uFlNvlghVmFywMNzkSZjS3bhDwv158phyYZulEeIbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100545/stv2813fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100545\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=YCBSrx17RLt7ZAYUUcjx1qvVpfz5-AzzD1gsHf0ttGET5QlHShGrRc0Q591Uue~NC60XkVjJqxF8zkwb~P1hpDvH6Bj6Vbnu4Pd5BbbmIAYiX5ftDH~Y44fZ3K~0cYzy9M2UQXaju0E1OSjJhuUv0Rke~SrpFOEWz00P37xXjmgRcQ602VgkuMY5iMli3pwqT79dwZJ6I2arE~5usYpszTLFfavUO7EhUO-oxuv-893DITqbms7OLq2-cjCcuuroTt7vBmwgENXNUMIPg52wZdGyF2enT9bVDlpwT4cfdXrssiCj72PddiuXa5WPx7Enz3R-lajtab-osPurynIrUQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100545&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assumed that the mass distribution of the lens galaxies is isothermal. More specifically, we either used the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) or ellipsoid (SIE) model for the lenses. Parameters such as the mass, ellipticity and the position angle (\u03b8<sub>e</sub>) of the lens model and the true (unlensed) position of the lensed quasar are allowed to be free. The positions and flux ratios<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> of the lensed quasar images served as constraints. We always begin with the SIS model and add further complexity such as adding more parameters only if the SIS results in a poor fit. The best-fitting parameters from the mass models are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92100547\" scrollto-destination=\"92100547\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting lens mass model parameters. The parameter \u03b8<sub>Ein</sub>, <em>e</em>, and \u03b8<sub>e</sub> denote the Einstein radius, ellipticity, and the position angle of the mass distribution, respectively. The numbers in bracket indicate which priors were used from the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\"
