.\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(\u00b0)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0114+0722\u00a0</td><td>0.83\u00a0</td><td>0.42\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0256+0153\u00a0</td><td>1.03\u00a0</td><td>0.74\u00a0</td><td>42\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0737+4825\u00a0</td><td>0.81\u00a0</td><td>0.25\u00a0</td><td>[\u221282]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0821+4542\u00a0</td><td>0.63\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>\u221221\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0921+2854\u00a0</td><td>0.96\u00a0</td><td>0.53\u00a0</td><td>28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>1.15\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>0.89\u00a0</td><td>[\u22120.553]\u00a0</td><td>[0.321]<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>0.84\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>52\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>1.03\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>0.87\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>1.15\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>1.14\u00a0</td><td>0.21\u00a0</td><td>[88]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>0.71\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>This is an SIS model with priors on the lens position. Instead of the ellipticity and position angle, the last two columns list the best-fitting offset (in arcseconds) of the lens from one of the lensed quasars in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> direction, respectively. We use the standard Cartesian convention where <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are positive to the right and up, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100547\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For SDSS J1330+3800, neither the SIS nor the SIE model could fit the constraints well. Hence, for this system, we used an SIS model with the lens galaxy position allowed to vary within the uncertainties from the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model. In a few other cases, we also used priors on the position angle of the lens based on the photometric models (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). In general, we could use the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> errors on the positions and fluxes of the lensed images but had to relax them<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> in a few cases in order to find a reasonable \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. The errors were relaxed up to \u223c0.15\u00a0arcsec and were always smaller than the pixel size. The best-fitting Einstein radii (or the velocity dispersions) of the BQLS lenses, which is a proxy for the mass of the lens galaxy, are similar to typical galaxy-scale lenses (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100549 id=\"92100549\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100550 id=\"92100550\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Properties of the BQLS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The basic properties of the 13 quasar lenses are summarized in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We also compare the image separation, magnitude, and redshift distributions of the newly discovered quasar lens systems with those of the SQLS sample in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In the redshift comparison, we exclude systems for which the lens redshifts are not known. There are two SQLS lens samples (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>): (i) \u2018all\u2019 \u2013 the entire lens sample which includes some heterogeneously selected lenses and (ii) \u2018stat\u2019 \u2013 this is a statistically well-defined sample with high completeness. The SQLS statistical lens sample is limited to the quasar redshift range of 0.6 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 2.2, <em>i</em>-band magnitude <em>i</em> &lt; 19.1, image separations 1\u2009arcsec &lt; \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 30\u2009arcsec, and flux ratios for doubles larger than 10<sup>\u22120.5</sup>, in order to accurately characterize the selection function.</p>                        <a id=\"92100552\" scrollto-destination=\"92100552\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the confirmed quasar lenses. The image separations \u0394\u03b8 are computed from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and the <em>i</em>-band PSF magnitudes are from the SDSS data base.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b8(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>1.717\u00a0</td><td>0.555\u00a0</td><td>2.32\u00a0</td><td>19.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>2.254\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.44\u00a0</td><td>20.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>2.952\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.53\u00a0</td><td>19.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>2.575\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.13\u00a0</td><td>17.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>4.819\u00a0</td><td>0.382\u00a0</td><td>1.59\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>1.724\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.15\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>1.553\u00a0</td><td>0.490\u00a0</td><td>2.30\u00a0</td><td>19.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>2.381\u00a0</td><td>0.799\u00a0</td><td>1.39\u00a0</td><td>20.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100552\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the BOSS sample size is much smaller, we show normalized distributions to facilitate qualitative comparison of the properties of these samples. The image separation distribution suggests that the BOSS sample finds a larger fraction of small image separation (\u0394\u03b8 \u2272 2\u00a0arcsec) lenses compared to the SQLS sample. One likely reason for this difference is that we preferentially selected small-separation lens candidates for follow-up confirmation because larger separation quasar pairs are more likely to be physical pairs rather than real lenses (e.g. Kochanek, Falco &amp; Mu\u00f1oz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>). Another possibility may be fibre collisions. Large-separation lenses are produced by clusters of galaxies typically at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5, and therefore there are usually many member galaxies around the quasar images that are selected as Constant MASS (CMASS) galaxies for spectroscopy. This may reduce the chance of these quasar images being spectroscopically observed by BOSS. As mentioned earlier, this was indeed the case for SDSS J2222+2745 where none of the quasar images were observed by BOSS while spectra were taken of several nearby member galaxies of this cluster lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that 7 out of the 13 confirmed quasar lens systems are located at <em>z</em> &gt; 2.2. The fraction of high-redshift quasar lenses is not particularly high compared with the \u2018all\u2019 SQLS sample (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). This result may be partly explained by the fact that some of the new lens systems were originally targeted as CMASS galaxies rather than quasars because of the dominant lens galaxy component. Indeed, for many of these cases, the lens galaxies are visible in the SDSS spectra which then provide the lens redshifts for these systems (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Spectroscopic quasars selected in this manner are not necessarily high-redshift quasars. This also explains the peak of the lens redshift distribution at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> \u223c 0.5, which is close to the median redshift of the BOSS CMASS galaxy sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of the BQLS lenses are fainter because BOSS target selection selects fainter quasars. The BOSS DR12 quasar catalogue contains 25 previously known lenses, many found by the SQLS. About two-thirds of this sample are bright lens systems (<em>i</em> &lt; 18) with quasars at low redshifts (<em>z</em> &lt; 2.2). We excluded this known sample before the visual selection of the BQLS lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A subsample of the BOSS quasars are selected homogeneously and have a well-defined selection function which is called the CORE sample (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Lenses present in the CORE sample could be used to define a statistical sample for the BQLS provided the visual selection process is calibrated. However, only two out of the 13 confirmed lenses are in the CORE sample (using the boss_target1 flag for QSO_CORE_MAIN). It is unlikely that our visual inspection process is highly inefficient, so it is unlikely that we are missing a large number of true lenses. Therefore, even if we were to detect most of the true lenses, a statistically well-defined sample derived from this parent sample will still be probably too small for any statistical study. The \u2018point-source\u2019 requirement for the CORE sample is probably the cause of this low yield.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100557 id=\"92100557\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>Quad fraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the 13 confirmed quasar lenses are two-image quasar lens systems. At galaxy scales, we expect about 15\u201320\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the lenses to be quadruply imaged for the BOSS quasar lens sample with <em>i</em> \u2272 20 \u2212 21 (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) which means we should expect two or more quad lenses in our sample. There are several possible explanations for the lack of quad lenses in the BOSS quasar lens sample. First of all, the BOSS quasar target selection selects only point sources to increase its efficiency (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), whereas small-separation quad lens systems are often classified as extended sources in the SDSS (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Indeed, all the four small-separation (\u0394\u03b8 &lt; 2\u00a0arcsec) quad lenses discovered in the SQLS (see Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) are found to be classified as extended sources in the SDSS data set. In addition, the visual inspection method might be biased against selecting quad lenses because the quads appear to have odd morphology. And, spectroscopic follow-up observations might be biased because single long-slit mode is used to target the double quasar candidate images along with the candidate lens galaxy for confirmation. Therefore, it is of great interest to apply more sophisticated algorithms (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to the quasars in BOSS to search for quad lenses that are missing in the current lens sample.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100559 id=\"92100559\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>Quasar pairs</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our follow-up spectroscopy identified an additional 11 quasar pairs with small angular separations of \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 3\u00a0arcsec (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for a summary). We expect most of these to be either projected pairs or binary quasars, based on their different SEDs and the lack of an obvious lens. Among the 11 quasar pairs, 7 pairs have the velocity difference \u0394<em>V</em> smaller than 2000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and therefore satisfy the criterion of physical binaries used in Hennawi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>). The velocity difference may also be useful for distinguishing binary quasars from lensed quasars. We find that the typical \u0394<em>V</em> of the confirmed lenses measured from our follow-up spectra is &lt;40 and \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in a few cases, which can be regarded as a typical error on our velocity difference measurements. From Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we find that most of the quasar pairs have velocity differences significantly larger than those of the confirmed lenses, indicating that they are less likely to be lensed images of a single source but rather are physically associated distinct quasars.</p>                        <a id=\"92100561\" scrollto-destination=\"92100561\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl7\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl7\" data-id=\"tbl7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of confirmed quasar pairs. See Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for the RA and Dec. of the brighter quasar image (A). The positions and the <em>i</em>-band magnitudes in this table are from the SDSS data base except for J0818+0601 where we used the astrometrically calibrated SOAR images.</p></div> </div><div J1548+2830\u00a0</td><td>15:48:50.776\u00a0</td><td>+28:30:12.714\u00a0</td><td>3.208\u00a0</td><td>1.487\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>20.8\u00a0</td><td>20.9\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2245+2548\u00a0</td><td>22:45:55.801\u00a0</td><td>+25:48:33.548\u00a0</td><td>2.995\u00a0</td><td>2.178\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td><td>20.4\u00a0</td><td>20.7\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div J0930+4614\u00a0</td><td>09:30:20.986\u00a0</td><td>+46:14:23.260\u00a0</td><td>2.393\u00a0</td><td>2.394\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0</td><td>18.4\u00a0</td><td>19.9\u00a0</td><td>111\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1043+4320\u00a0</td><td>10:43:25.025\u00a0</td><td>+43:20:48.958\u00a0</td><td>2.245\u00a0</td><td>2.225\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>21.4\u00a0</td><td>20.7\u00a0</td><td>1778\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1124+5710\u00a0</td><td>11:24:55.440\u00a0</td><td>+57:10:58.120\u00a0</td><td>2.309\u00a0</td><td>2.315\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td><td>18.6\u00a0</td><td>19.7\u00a0</td><td>496\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1309+5617\u00a0</td><td>13:09:27.338\u00a0</td><td>+56:17:41.161\u00a0</td><td>2.513\u00a0</td><td>2.515\u00a0</td><td>2.8\u00a0</td><td>20.5\u00a0</td><td>21.6\u00a0</td><td>169\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1405+1350\u00a0</td><td>14:05:56.865\u00a0</td><td>+13:50:39.827\u00a0</td><td>2.345\u00a0</td><td>2.361\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>21.7\u00a0</td><td>22.0\u00a0</td><td>1400\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1548+2830\u00a0</td><td>15:48:50.776\u00a0</td><td>+28:30:12.714\u00a0</td><td>3.208\u00a0</td><td>1.487\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>20.8\u00a0</td><td>20.9\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2245+2548\u00a0</td><td>22:45:55.801\u00a0</td><td>+25:48:33.548\u00a0</td><td>2.995\u00a0</td><td>2.178\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td><td>20.4\u00a0</td><td>20.7\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100561\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In general, there are still only a small number of quasar pairs known (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and our sample adds significantly to the existing pair samples. For comparison, the SQLS only identified eight binary quasars with \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 3\u00a0arcsec (see Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, for a compilation), which is comparable to the number of new binary quasars from the BQLS. The small-separation binary quasars have been used to study the very small scale clustering of quasars to discuss the possible role of mergers in enhancing quasar activities (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>; Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Shen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Projected quasar pairs are also useful for studying the distribution of absorbers around quasars (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100563 id=\"92100563\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the initial results from BQLS, a systematic search for lensed quasars in the SDSS-III/BOSS data. We applied the same technique that we used for finding lensed quasars in the SDSS DR7 (SQLS). Here, we report the discovery of 13 confirmed quasar lenses. In addition, we present the discovery of 11 quasar pairs, some of which may consist of physical binaries. This subsample may still contain a few unrecognized lenses. The sample of new lenses includes one of the highest redshift lensed quasar (SDSS J1452+4224, <em>z</em> \u2248 4.8) found to date. SDSS J1442+4055 was also discovered independently by Sergeyev et\u00a0al. 2015 (submitted to MNRAS, private communication from Luis J. Goicoechea). All the confirmed lenses from the BQLS have only two images. The lack of quad lenses is probably because BOSS only selects point-like quasars. We note that our follow-up observations are still incomplete with an additional \u223c50 good lens candidates that need verification. However, this sample is likely to have fewer real lenses since we conducted the follow-up observations of the most promising candidates first.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to the SQLS, the selection function of the BQLS sample is complicated owing to the complex selection of the initial BOSS quasar targets. In addition to the incomplete follow-up observations, a complex selection function prevents us from using the BQLS sample for statistical studies of either the lens population or cosmology (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The CORE sample from BOSS, which is a uniform and well-defined quasar sample could be used to produce a statistical BQLS sample, yielded only two lenses. This is probably because the quasars are required to be point-like in the CORE sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A qualitative comparison of the initial BQLS sample with the SQLS shows that BQLS lenses are somewhat fainter and have smaller image separations, presumably due to the BOSS selection criteria. Furthermore, the BQLS and SQLS lensed quasars have similar redshift distributions in spite of the higher redshift selection used for BOSS quasars. This is because many of the lenses in our sample were photometrically identified as galaxies before they were spectroscopically confirmed by BOSS to be quasars. In addition, about half of the lensed quasars have redshifts lower than the quasar redshift range targeted by BOSS. These lenses would have been missed in the absence of BOSS CMASS galaxy spectroscopy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This study provides useful guidance for ongoing quasar lens surveys in Hyper Suprime-Cam<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> and Dark Energy Survey (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) in which even fainter quasar lenses will be discovered.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The work of MO and AM was supported in part by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. This work was also supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research from the JSPS (26800093 and 24740171). AM would like to thank S. More and J. Silverman for useful suggestions. AM acknowledges the support of the Japan Society for Promotion of Science (JSPS) fellowship. AMM acknowledges the support of NSF grant AST-1211146. The authors would like to thank the anonymous referee for useful suggestions that improved the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, and the US Department of Energy Office of Science. The SDSS-III web site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss3.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss3.org/</a>. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, Harvard University, the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, the Michigan State/Notre Dame/JINA Participation Group, Johns Hopkins University, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics, Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, New Mexico State University, New York University, Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, University of Portsmouth, Princeton University, the Spanish Participation Group, University of Tokyo, University of Utah, Vanderbilt University, University of Virginia, University of Washington, and Yale University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based in part on data collected at Subaru Telescope, which is operated by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan. Use of the UH 2.2-m telescope for the observations is supported by NAOJ. Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. A part of this work is based on observations obtained at the MDM Observatory, operated by Dartmouth College, Columbia University, Ohio State University, Ohio University, and the University of Michigan. Based on observations obtained at the SOAR telescope, which is a joint project of the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia, e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (MCTI) da Rep\u00fablica Federativa do Brasil, the US National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), and Michigan State University (MSU).</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> is distributed by the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, which are operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Redshifts from Ly\u00a0\u03b1 at such high redshifts are strongly affected by the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 forest (McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Therefore, we give fewer significant digits on the redshift estimate.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The flux ratios are often known to be affected by dust, substructure, intrinsic quasar variability and microlensing. Thus, a simple globally smooth models such as the ones tested here may fail to fit the flux ratios and cannot necessarily be used to rule out the lens hypothesis.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This is reasonable because the errors from <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> are known to be an underestimate (e.g. Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.naoj.org/Projects/HSC/surveyplan.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.naoj.org/Projects/HSC/surveyplan.html</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100578 id=\"92100578\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Agnello</div>\r\n <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Kelly</div>\r\n <div class=\"given-names\">B. content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>This is an SIS model with priors on the lens position. We use the standard Cartesian convention where <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are positive to the right and up, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting lens mass model parameters. Instead of the ellipticity and position angle, the last two columns list the best-fitting offset (in arcseconds) of the lens from one of the lensed quasars in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> direction, respectively. We use the standard Cartesian convention where <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are positive to the right and up, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals widget-instance-SiteWideModals\">\n        <div id=\"revealModal\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <div The \u2018Selection\u2019 column indicates the method(s) with \u2018M\u2019 for morphological selection, \u2018C\u2019 for colour selection, and \u2018S\u2019 for spectroscopic selection (see the text for details). Several candidates were selected by multiple methods. \u2018Observation\u2019 indicates the telescope (S-Subaru or K-Keck), the date and setup of the spectroscopic observations (see also Section 3.1). \u2018Result\u2019 indicates the conclusion from the follow-up spectroscopy as well as imaging observations described in Section 3.2. The <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> are taken from the BOSS DR12 catalogue which has redshifts corrected after visual inspection of the spectra. The \u2018Selection\u2019 column indicates the method(s) with \u2018M\u2019 for morphological selection, \u2018C\u2019 for colour selection, and \u2018S\u2019 for spectroscopic selection (see the text for details). The <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> are taken from the BOSS DR12 catalogue which has redshifts corrected after visual inspection of the spectra. $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"icon-menu_share\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Share</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ShareDrop\" class=\"addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_20x20_style f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_email\"><span>Email</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_twitter\"><span>Twitter</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_facebook\"><span>Facebook</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-search-dropdown\">\r\n        <div class=\"mobile-search-inner-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearch\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search\">\r\n                        <label for=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Navbar Search Filter</label>\r\n                        <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                            <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n<option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\">This issue</option><option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\">All  Monthly Notices of the Royal      </optgroup>\r\n                        </select>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <label for=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Mobile Microsite Search Term</label>\r\n                        <input class=\"mobile-search-input mobile-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" placeholder=\"Search\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\">\r\n\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search-icon mobile-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f456%2f2%2f1595%2f1070908\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100487 id=\"92100487\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of 13 confirmed two-image quasar lenses from a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in the SDSS-III Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS). We adopted a methodology similar to that used in the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS). In addition to the confirmed lenses, we report 11 quasar pairs with small angular separations ( \u2272 2\u00a0arcsec) confirmed from our spectroscopy, which are either projected pairs, physical binaries, or possibly quasar lens systems whose lens galaxies have not yet been detected. The newly discovered quasar lens system, SDSS J1452+4224 at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 4.8 is one of the highest redshift multiply imaged quasars found to date. Furthermore, we have over 50 good lens candidates yet to be followed up. Owing to the heterogeneous selection of BOSS quasars, the lens sample presented here does not have a well-defined selection function.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100489 id=\"92100489\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitationally lensed quasars provide a unique tool to study the Universe. In particular, the time-variable nature of quasars enable us to measure the arrival time difference between quasar multiple images, which may be a powerful probe of cosmology (e.g. Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Applications of gravitationally lensed quasars such as time delay cosmography (e.g. Coles <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), constraints on the quasar luminosity function (e.g. Comerford, Haiman &amp; Schaye <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Richards et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), constraints on dark energy (e.g. Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and study of the host galaxy and/or black hole properties (e.g. Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Mosquera et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are still limited by small number statistics, indicating the importance of finding new gravitationally lensed quasars in wide-field surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) considerably advanced the field by discovering nearly 50 new quasar lenses. The SQLS was based upon the large sample of spectroscopically confirmed quasars in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey \u2013 I/II (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). Candidates were first selected from the \u223c100\u2009000 spectroscopic quasars and their SDSS images were then examined to identify quasars with extended morphology or with nearby companion objects of similar colour. The lens candidates were then confirmed with various facilities to construct a secure sample of gravitationally lensed quasars. Thanks to the well-studied selection function (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), a subsample of the SQLS quasar lenses was used to place statistical limits on dark energy and the evolution of massive galaxies that act as lenses (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS; Dawson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) of the SDSS-III (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is a new spectroscopic survey to measure the expansion rate of the Universe. In addition to an extensive spectroscopic survey of <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5 galaxies, BOSS has obtained spectra of \u223c300\u2009000 quasars (Alam et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) with over 180\u00a0000 in the redshift range 2.15 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 4 in order to detect baryon acoustic oscillation signatures in the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 absorption features of their spectra. The large number of BOSS quasars suggests that it should contain a large number of gravitationally lensed quasars. However, the lensing rate of the BOSS quasar sample is likely smaller than that of the SDSS-II quasar sample because BOSS largely targets point-like quasar candidates in order to increase the survey efficiency. In this case, lensed quasars where the images are not individually resolved would appear extended and would tend to be excluded by the BOSS selection function. On the other hand, the typical BOSS quasar is at a higher redshift (<em>z</em> \u223c 2\u20133 Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) than the typical SDSS-I/II quasars (<em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20132) and this higher average redshift may partly compensate for the lower lensing rate due to the morphological target selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thus started a new survey for gravitationally lensed quasars from BOSS called the BOSS quasar lens survey (BQLS). The basic strategy follows that of the SQLS in that we select quasar lens candidates by examining the SDSS images of BOSS quasars and conduct additional observations of any promising quasar lens candidates. In this paper, we present 13 confirmed quasar lenses from the BQLS. In addition, we also identify 11 quasar close pairs with not quite identical but similar spectra. Some of these may be true gravitational lenses but could not be confirmed due to lack of detection of a lens galaxy or spectra being slightly different due to effects such as microlensing and dust extinction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we describe the selection of our lens candidates. In Section 3, we describe the additional observations undertaken for a detailed examination of the most promising lens candidates. The mass modelling of the lenses is described in Section 4. We compare the confirmed lenses to the SQLS lens sample and present our general findings in Section 5. Section 6 presents our summary and conclusions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100495 id=\"92100495\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We selected candidate quasar lens systems from the imaging and spectroscopic data of SDSS-III/BOSS. The SDSS uses a dedicated 2.5-metre telescope at Apache Point Observatory in New Mexico (Gunn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The SDSS imaging data uses five (<em>ugriz</em>) broad-band filters and has a limiting magnitude of <em>r</em> \u223c 22.5, which were used to select various targets including quasars for spectroscopic observations (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The SDSS-III/BOSS survey uses an upgraded multi-object fibre spectrograph which can simultaneously take spectra of 1000 objects with a resolving power <em>R</em> \u223c 2000 and a wavelength coverage of 3600 &lt; \u03bb &lt; 10\u2009400\u2009\u00c5 (Smee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We largely followed the procedures established in the SQLS for the lens candidate selection process. In the SQLS, however, there were also image separation and flux ratio limits for constructing a complete lens sample for statistical studies. In SDSS-III, constructing a well-defined statistical sample is much more challenging because of the complex nature of the quasar target selection (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Thus, we first adopted a simple approach of applying the SQLS-like selection criteria and then choosing the best lens candidates by visually inspecting the SDSS images of all of the resulting lens candidates. Below we describe these procedures in more detail.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The selection method for the underlying SDSS-III/BOSS spectroscopic quasar sample is presented in Ross et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Currently all of the BOSS data are public, and the quasar catalogue we used is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org/dr12/algorithms/boss-dr12-quasar-catalog/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss.org/dr12/algorithms/boss-dr12-quasar-catalog/</a>. From the spectroscopic quasar catalogue, we selected quasar lens candidates using a method similar to SQLS, in which morphological and colour criteria were used to select lens candidates from the object catalogue. The full details of the SQLS selection algorithm are presented in Oguri et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and Inada et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). While the SQLS selection criteria were optimized for selecting low-redshift (<em>z</em> &lt; 2.2) quasar lens candidates, an extension of the selection algorithm to higher redshifts is discussed in Inada et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). In this paper, we adopted a modified version of these morphological and colour selection criteria as described below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The morphological selection approach identified spectroscopic quasars that are poorly fit by the imaging point spread function (PSF). Even though BOSS targeted point-like quasars, there are extended objects with a spectroscopic classification of a quasar in BOSS which were originally identified as galaxies and targeted as part of the galaxy follow-up programmes or ancillary programmes targeting AGNs. Therefore, we applied the morphological selection to find small image separation lensed quasars which appear as extended quasar-like sources. Specifically, we used the following object parameters; <span class=\"monospace\">type</span>, which describes the classification of objects as stars (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\tt type}=6$|\u2060</span>) or galaxies (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\tt type}=3$|\u2060</span>); <span class=\"monospace\">lnlStar</span>, which is the logarithm of the likelihood of objects being fitted by the PSF of the field; <span class=\"monospace\">lnlDeV</span>, which is the logarithm of the likelihood of objects being fitted by the de Vaucouleurs profile. The parameters <span class=\"monospace\">lnlStar</span> and <span class=\"monospace\">lnlDeV</span> are available for each broad-band. For quasars at 0.7 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 3, we selected lens candidates whose <em>gri</em>-band object parameters satisfy <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlStar} &lt; -1$|</span> for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt type}=3$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlDeV} &lt; -15$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt lnlStar} - {\\tt lnlDeV} &lt; -5$|</span> for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\tt type}=6$|\u2060</span>. For quasars at <em>z</em> &gt; 3, we used the same criteria as above but only for the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands. There were \u223c3000 candidates selected by these criteria.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a given spectroscopic quasar, the colour selection method searches for nearby objects with similar colours out to a maximum image separation of \u0394\u03b8 = 30\u00a0arcsec. For quasars at 0.7 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 3.4, we used all five bands and select objects with colour differences smaller than 0.1 for <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> and <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and smaller than 0.2 for <em>u</em> \u2212 <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>, where the colours were computed using PSF magnitudes. For quasars at <em>z</em> &gt; 3.4, we used only the <em>griz</em>-bands and similar thresholds for the colour differences of 0.1 for <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and 0.2 for <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>. We also required that the <em>i</em>-band magnitude difference of the two objects was smaller than 1. When the angular separation of the two objects were small (&lt;3.5\u00a0arcsec), we used relaxed colour criteria as the SDSS photometry might not be reliable (see Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). This colour selection method led to a sample of \u223c2000 candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then visually inspected all the morphological and colour selected lens candidates. The visual inspection was performed by one of the authors (MO) to define \u2018good\u2019 lens candidates that have relatively high chance of being true lens systems. Here, the goodness of the candidates was judged by various factors including the presence of multiple components with quasar-like colours or nearby galaxies that might act as lenses. Most of the false positives removed in the visual inspection are either single quasars with contamination from bright nearby objects and obvious quasar-galaxy superpositions. Large-separation ( \u2273 5\u00a0arcsec) quasar lenses are much less common, and hence large-separation lens candidates are not regarded as good unless putative lens galaxies or clusters are seen in between the candidate quasar images. We finally selected \u223c80 good candidates and an additional \u223c70 possible lens candidates from the morphological selection, and \u223c75 good candidates and \u223c65 possible lens candidates from the colour selection. There is an overlap of \u223c20 good candidates between the morphology and colour selected samples. The number of lens candidates, requiring observational follow-up studies was reduced by a factor of \u223c20 through the visual inspection. This suggests that our approach is an efficient approach to find the most promising lens candidates. Nevertheless, it is possible that we missed some true gravitational lens systems in the course of the visual inspection. For example, we are likely to miss quasars that are fainter and do not visually look star-like which includes some small image-separation lenses and possibly quadruply imaged systems. We may also have missed systems with atypical image configurations, odd colours or highly anomalous flux ratios.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that Dahle et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) discovered a gravitationally lensed sextuple quasar with a maximum image separation of 15.1\u00a0arcsec, SDSS J2222+2745, from the SDSS-III data. They searched for strong lens candidates by visually inspecting photometrically identified clusters of galaxies. Even though this lens system meets our image separation criteria, none of the lensed quasars from SDSS J2222+2745 were selected for spectroscopy by BOSS so this source is not in our parent sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some gravitationally lensed quasars have been discovered by identifying quasar spectral features superposed on the spectra of lens galaxies (e.g. Johnston et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) although this technique of identifying compound objects spectroscopically has primarily discovered many examples of lensed star-forming galaxies (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>). As a complementary approach to the SQLS selection technique, we also searched for lensed quasars using this technique. We identified instances of quasar-galaxy superpositions in the BOSS spectra with quasars at <em>z</em> &lt; 5.5 and galaxies with redshifts lower than the quasars (Zinn et\u00a0al., in preparation). The initial sample had 17 good candidates out of which three systems were followed-up spectroscopically as part of the BQLS sample. Currently, this search has produced \u223c100 candidates with a \u2018good\u2019 visual quality flag and will be presented in Zinn et\u00a0al. (in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The BOSS DR12 catalogue has some known lenses, several of which are in the SQLS. This known sample was excluded prior to the visual inspection of the candidates. In total, we identified about 250 new lens candidates for further study. In the next section, we present initial follow-up results of the most promising quasar lens candidates.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100505 id=\"92100505\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>DATA: OBSERVATION, REDUCTION AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our follow-up observations consist of imaging and spectroscopic observations. We first attempt to obtain follow-up images for the good lens candidates, and conduct follow-up spectroscopic observations only when the follow-up images show evidence for gravitational lensing. However, it was not possible to follow this strategy strictly due to observing constraints. In some cases, we obtained follow-up spectra before we conducted imaging follow-up observations. Among these systems, those with clear differences in the spectra were thus not observed with imaging. Since the spectroscopic observations are very informative for confirming or ruling out the lensing hypotheses of the candidates, below we first present the complete spectroscopic follow-up results for the best 55 candidates, and then present imaging follow-up results for confirmed gravitational lens systems. The full imaging follow-up results will be presented in an upcoming paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100507 id=\"92100507\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>Spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> summarizes our spectroscopic observations. We obtained spectra of five candidates with the Low Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (LRIS; Oke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) on the Keck telescope on 2013 September 7. We used the 1.0\u00a0arcsec slit, the 400/3400 grism for the blue channel and the 400/8500 grating for the red channel. The spectral resolution was <em>R</em> \u223c 600 in the blue channel and <em>R</em> \u223c 1300 in the red channel. The red channel was binned to give 0.27\u2009arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The unbinned blue channel has 0.135\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. We also obtained spectra of 50 candidates with the Faint Object Camera and Spectrograph (FOCAS; Kashikawa et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) on the Subaru telescope on 2014 May 2, 2015 Feb 19, and 2015 June 19. In all of the FOCAS observations we used the 1.0\u00a0arcsec slit, but adopted two different configurations depending on the quasar redshifts; one is the grism and filter set of 300B/L600 to cover the wavelength range of 3700\u20136000 \u00c5, and the other is 300B/SY47 4700\u20139100 \u00c5. Both data sets have a spectral resolution of <em>R</em> \u223c 400\u2013500. The data were binned 2 \u00d7 2 on the detector, providing a spatial resolution of 0.21\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. In all of the observations, the long-slit was aligned to observe both putative quasar images simultaneously. The data were reduced using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> tasks.</p>                        <a id=\"92100509\" scrollto-destination=\"92100509\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of spectroscopic observations. The \u2018Selection\u2019 column indicates the method(s) with \u2018M\u2019 for morphological selection, \u2018C\u2019 for colour selection, and \u2018S\u2019 for spectroscopic selection (see the text for details). Several candidates were selected by multiple methods. \u2018Observation\u2019 indicates the telescope (S-Subaru or K-Keck), the date and setup of the spectroscopic observations (see also Section 3.1). \u2018Result\u2019 indicates the conclusion from the follow-up spectroscopy as well as imaging observations described in Section 3.2. The <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> are taken from the BOSS DR12 catalogue which has redshifts corrected after visual inspection of the spectra. The last column has redshifts from the follow-up spectra except when marked with<sup><em>a</em></sup> which are taken from the BOSS spectrum.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. The \u2018Selection\u2019 column indicates the method(s) with \u2018M\u2019 for morphological selection, \u2018C\u2019 for colour selection, and \u2018S\u2019 for spectroscopic selection (see the text for details). J2314\u22120108\u00a0</td><td>23:14:24.50\u00a0</td><td>\u221201:08:58.7\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>3.455\u00a0</td><td>S, 2015 Feb (300B/SY47)\u00a0</td><td>1080\u00a0</td><td>Different SED\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100509\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We found that 13 out of the 55 quasar lens candidates contain two quasar components with identical redshifts and similarities in the spectral energy distributions (SEDs). Together with the analysis of the imaging observations presented below, we conclude that these 13 systems are gravitationally lensed quasars. Our spectroscopy also identified an additional 11 quasar pairs with either almost identical or slightly different redshifts. Properties of these 11 quasar pairs will be discussed in Sections 3.3 and 5.3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> presents the spectra for the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including the 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars. For five of the quasar lens systems, the lens galaxies are bright enough to be clearly detected in one of the quasar spectra. We successfully measured the lens redshift for these lens systems (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). For an additional three quasar systems, the lens galaxies are bright and their redshifts were derived from the SDSS-III spectra. The subsequent spectra do not cover the red wavelength range where these lens galaxies can be detected easily.</p>                        <a id=\"92100512\" scrollto-destination=\"92100512\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=ShFhVBb739wh6wn-DVTi~pe7Zr6yrnnWLm~SNm2t6CxcdYJv~cMUp1e2nJ7gyg8v1cm7s5KgNMxssmlQafMvjwwyutrwazYaogACJOtmHGEQG6kw8mMyl1YfmD42RQo5MHCeU~~fPdcF5FmU3Wjb87JBrjfS5xxMNJrPdiALN9~OF~oMl2pqq9RNwwx5WwjzdCfTTobwFuvci1taVx8M4BBVT1I6J52SVne8MFwwTsVNeoz7ThkL5fcq~Frm5UmbgzahyxIxxJF77ri6OT-jBYN1MvTKUod12Gx4ne7kEBBnv2AEFn6KpAKYt-BW~Q38v-P3u9Xn2WaHHnxOQKMIjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table 1). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux F\u03bb is in units of 10\u221217erg\u2009cm\u22122\u2009s\u22121\u2009\u00c5 \u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100512/stv2813fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100512\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=tedkoQPBc~RyMrRVPNM1oRHbXslVhA-7BZ5bsBMeV8eoxX8B-C4FLLaCgfqyTSy3L0qNk0Wj2~tOb~PRelSOHzx5vP6cMDIVO6sSGKiziDfyXUHepE5dTOTYrurJBPMRwMvktDr6GRGmp5pf04YDblwhq3dZxpy9MBHpEVuCVKIUIgidyyTH2cFAkOU226BSKUDv58IzEWcMo5wM3CohXOgPbd2TYWCgaKUkt2pUeJfEMqjAISaUM21XV9vbZU6B0m4lyzC4U4codUlVG78q5p5psxopewjbIP3TvuyqOYYNX3PzTh7-T464QpBJiifo1tH9Fnci7~IWvbMyh54OAw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100512&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux <em>F</em><sub>\u03bb</sub> is in units of 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009\u00c5 <sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=ShFhVBb739wh6wn-DVTi~pe7Zr6yrnnWLm~SNm2t6CxcdYJv~cMUp1e2nJ7gyg8v1cm7s5KgNMxssmlQafMvjwwyutrwazYaogACJOtmHGEQG6kw8mMyl1YfmD42RQo5MHCeU~~fPdcF5FmU3Wjb87JBrjfS5xxMNJrPdiALN9~OF~oMl2pqq9RNwwx5WwjzdCfTTobwFuvci1taVx8M4BBVT1I6J52SVne8MFwwTsVNeoz7ThkL5fcq~Frm5UmbgzahyxIxxJF77ri6OT-jBYN1MvTKUod12Gx4ne7kEBBnv2AEFn6KpAKYt-BW~Q38v-P3u9Xn2WaHHnxOQKMIjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table 1).
