The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux F\u03bb is in units of 10\u221217erg\u2009cm\u22122\u2009s\u22121\u2009\u00c5 \u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100512/stv2813fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100512\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=tedkoQPBc~RyMrRVPNM1oRHbXslVhA-7BZ5bsBMeV8eoxX8B-C4FLLaCgfqyTSy3L0qNk0Wj2~tOb~PRelSOHzx5vP6cMDIVO6sSGKiziDfyXUHepE5dTOTYrurJBPMRwMvktDr6GRGmp5pf04YDblwhq3dZxpy9MBHpEVuCVKIUIgidyyTH2cFAkOU226BSKUDv58IzEWcMo5wM3CohXOgPbd2TYWCgaKUkt2pUeJfEMqjAISaUM21XV9vbZU6B0m4lyzC4U4codUlVG78q5p5psxopewjbIP3TvuyqOYYNX3PzTh7-T464QpBJiifo1tH9Fnci7~IWvbMyh54OAw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100512&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of the 24 confirmed quasar pairs, including 13 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). In each panel, vertical dotted lines show the wavelengths of the quasar emission lines. Vertical short bars indicate the wavelengths of absorption features in the spectrum of the lens galaxy, which are shown only for lens systems for which lens galaxies are sufficiently bright to be detected in one of the quasar spectra. The redshifts shown in each panel correspond to the quasar. The flux <em>F</em><sub>\u03bb</sub> is in units of 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009\u00c5 <sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100513 id=\"92100513\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>Imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We imaged a subsample of the most promising candidates in two to three bands with the goal of detecting the lens galaxy. At minimum, these imaging data should better resolve the small separation lensed quasar images to provide the basic constraints required for mass modelling. The majority of the lenses from the BQLS sample were observed with the Tektronix 2048\u00d72048 CCD camera (Tek2k, with a pixel resolution of 0.22\u00a0arcsec) on the UH88 telescope. A few of the candidates were observed with other telescopes. A summary of these observations is given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> which includes the exposure times for each filter. We used the FOCAS instrument with 2 \u00d7 2 binning on Subaru giving a pixel resolution of 0.208\u00a0arcsec, the SOI instrument (pixel resolution of 0.15\u00a0arcsec) on the SOuthern Astrophysical Research (SOAR) telescope and the OSMOS instrument (pixel resolution of 0.273\u00a0arcsec) on the Hiltner telescope of the MDM observatory. We processed the data in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> by following standard procedures. The seeing of our imaging data is better than 1\u00a0arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"92100515\" scrollto-destination=\"92100515\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2015 Feb 20\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>OSMOS\u00a0</td><td>2013 Apr 08\u00a0</td><td>1200 (<em>g</em>) 2100 (<em>r</em>) 900 (<em>i,z</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>FOCAS\u00a0</td><td>2015 Jun 19\u00a0</td><td>270 (<em>R</em>) 360 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2012 Sep 17\u00a0</td><td>960 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div (<em>I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>3060 (<em>V</em>) 2880 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V</em>) 2160 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2015 Feb 20\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>OSMOS\u00a0</td><td>2013 Apr 08\u00a0</td><td>1200 (<em>g</em>) 2100 (<em>r</em>) 900 (<em>i,z</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>FOCAS\u00a0</td><td>2015 Jun 19\u00a0</td><td>270 (<em>R</em>) 360 (<em>I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>SOI\u00a0</td><td>2013 Feb 12\u00a0</td><td>420 (<em>g,r,i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2014 Feb 21\u00a0</td><td>1440 (<em>V</em>) 1800 (<em>R</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>Tek2k\u00a0</td><td>2012 Sep 17\u00a0</td><td>960 (<em>V,I</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em> Tek2k is on the UH88 telescope, OSMOS is on the Hiltner telescope, FOCAS is on the Subaru telescope and SOI is at the SOAR telescope.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100515\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In most cases, the imaging reveals two point-like components with a hint of extended emission close to one of those components indicating presence of a lens galaxy. We use <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to model each of these components and to measure their fluxes and positions. The quasars are assumed to be point sources convolved with the PSF and the galaxy is modelled with a S\u00e9rsic profile. The use of point sources for the quasar components is reasonable because all the quasars are at high redshifts <em>z</em> &gt; 1. We use the nearby stars as a model for the PSF. We first fit models to the two quasars without the lens. Next, we fit models including the lens. Both modelling results are compared and the latter model is accepted if the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> and the residuals have improved. In the cases when it was difficult to fit the S\u00e9rsic index of the galaxy's light profile, we held it fixed at <em>n</em> = 4, since the de Vaucouleurs profile (de Vaucouleurs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1948</a>) is a good model for early-type galaxies. The modelling results for all of the 13 confirmed lenses are presented in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. For each lens, we show the reddest available image (left-hand panel) where the contribution from the lens galaxy is easier to see than in the other bands, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model which includes the lens galaxy (second panel from left) and the residuals from this model (third panel from left). For comparison, we also show the residuals from the model without the lens galaxy in the right-most panel.</p>                        <a id=\"92100517\" scrollto-destination=\"92100517\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=OQrNIi6oraYN2E8mRAjbqcVVUBChn6rQtJvZfkckOwutaXQYEmQhizWQW4h6QsIxRf8sGL3~329PxBBJ4~57QlRymo5BsA4i2~BvQIJejjyMbPPyyOld2q-Wr8Q34ivolKV~JdD0nS8g2pWF2ctVUy5YQu0kg2xVdauSXupX-DI92IdgN2-ZCOpZWMu76uP6irTfxdZWcVZ~QrT7t-KO4DV42fkuubbvARL6gv03V2YHJAnoI0xiSjhQJjZ0TKz-g8UKYMKcqkMqiKiC7TGX22Nwe0PoBgKk84t12T212LorfIqI17SwzhN9m1uIAM4MaExuD~xbPvMsMCvJM6qwzw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the galfit model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100517/stv2813fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=ElG1wBWd-ahW6cA8EjQN9G97ctXiK7Uh9ZMh50usgmjhzrKqry0RxqCBy~zXpZ4y9sQaO8tzEz60qyfdZrcVOne8DqPeMDlBqzd2fzH7GVCotrxk-wgloYMeRwqUvkPfVFKXsCc6baz8zBvu9Wv6V78b9WG38gOYYaR7witHBsyfbPaKwZk7w1uBcBPBRu6Vgmgn3WehWBSr2ZHSHz1lANqyM-9jin2oMv~lEljk8TRdl4sd5u4WZQqoQvwbJGPs4L3mdv3EsugZdvsHUTawNUEwCS5TfzbyX4BQFA8bM8hd5WwfWPWndtKWDIDIe2qGa84lrcCvlxFPoiWnOW86ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100517&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=OQrNIi6oraYN2E8mRAjbqcVVUBChn6rQtJvZfkckOwutaXQYEmQhizWQW4h6QsIxRf8sGL3~329PxBBJ4~57QlRymo5BsA4i2~BvQIJejjyMbPPyyOld2q-Wr8Q34ivolKV~JdD0nS8g2pWF2ctVUy5YQu0kg2xVdauSXupX-DI92IdgN2-ZCOpZWMu76uP6irTfxdZWcVZ~QrT7t-KO4DV42fkuubbvARL6gv03V2YHJAnoI0xiSjhQJjZ0TKz-g8UKYMKcqkMqiKiC7TGX22Nwe0PoBgKk84t12T212LorfIqI17SwzhN9m1uIAM4MaExuD~xbPvMsMCvJM6qwzw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"galfit modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the galfit model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100517/stv2813fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=ElG1wBWd-ahW6cA8EjQN9G97ctXiK7Uh9ZMh50usgmjhzrKqry0RxqCBy~zXpZ4y9sQaO8tzEz60qyfdZrcVOne8DqPeMDlBqzd2fzH7GVCotrxk-wgloYMeRwqUvkPfVFKXsCc6baz8zBvu9Wv6V78b9WG38gOYYaR7witHBsyfbPaKwZk7w1uBcBPBRu6Vgmgn3WehWBSr2ZHSHz1lANqyM-9jin2oMv~lEljk8TRdl4sd5u4WZQqoQvwbJGPs4L3mdv3EsugZdvsHUTawNUEwCS5TfzbyX4BQFA8bM8hd5WwfWPWndtKWDIDIe2qGa84lrcCvlxFPoiWnOW86ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100517&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> modelling results for the quasar lens sample using the reddest available band as labelled in each case. For each lens system, the columns from left to right are the data, the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model including the lens galaxy and the residuals with and without the lens galaxy, respectively. The flux scales in the data and model images match but they are different from the residual images. The flux scales of both residual images match. All images have the standard orientation with north up and east on the left. All images are 51\u00a0pixels on the side, which is \u223c11\u00a0arcsec for all systems except for J1442+4055 (\u223c14\u00a0arcsec) and J1458\u22120202 (\u223c8\u00a0arcsec).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We performed relative photometry of the lenses by comparing them to nearby stars with known SDSS magnitudes. First, we used the software from Astrometry.net (Lang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to determine the orientations of the images and the positions of the stars, except for SDSS J1458\u22120202 and SDSS J1452+4224 where the astrometry was determined manually. For every lens in every band available from the imaging, we measured the fluxes of about a dozen stars using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). The zero-points were determined by comparing the SDSS magnitudes to the fluxes of the stars. Owing to the differences between the SDSS filters and those used for the follow up observations, we had to apply appropriate filter conversions to the fluxes. We adopted the conversions from Jester et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and Lupton (2005, unpublished) which are available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.sdss3.org/dr8/algorithms/sdssUBVRITransform.php\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.sdss3.org/dr8/algorithms/sdssUBVRITransform.php</a>. The zero-points were then used for determining the magnitudes of the lensed quasars and lens galaxies. The results of the relative astrometry and photometry are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The best-fitting parameters of the S\u00e9rsic model assumed for the lens galaxies are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92100519\" scrollto-destination=\"92100519\"></a>\r\n<div </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">S\u00e9rsic parameters of the lens galaxies. The parameters <em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, <em>n</em>, <em>e</em>, and \u03b8<sub>e</sub> denote the effective radius, S\u00e9rsic index, ellipticity, and the position angle (measured counter-clockwise from north where north is up at 0\u00b0), respectively. See Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> for the magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>e</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>n</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>e</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(\u00b0)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J0114+0722\u00a0</td><td>0.84 \u00b1 14.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>0.87 \u00b1 0.34\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>0.75 \u00b1 0.16\u00a0</td><td>\u221216.3 \u00b1 9.7\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>0.61 \u00b1 0.15\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>0.58 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>15.5 \u00b1 7.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>0.99 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td><td>4.19 \u00b1 0.70\u00a0</td><td>0.21 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>68.2 \u00b1 6.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>1.09 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>0.30 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>\u221223.8 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>2.13 \u00b1 0.24\u00a0</td><td>3.81 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td><td>0.36 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>30.6 \u00b1 1.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>3.57 \u00b1 2.09\u00a0</td><td>5.90 \u00b1 1.92\u00a0</td><td>0.37 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>87.2 \u00b1 5.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>0.38 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td><td>[4.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.00]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100520\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100521 id=\"92100521\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>Notes on interesting individual systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss the properties of some of the interesting systems from the BQLS.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100523 id=\"92100523\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-1>SDSS J0818+0601</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectrum shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> indicates that the two stellar components separated by \u0394\u03b8 \u223c 1\u00a0arcsec have similar spectra (\u0394<em>V</em> = 226\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), including broad absorption features in the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines. However, no lens galaxy was found in our SOAR images (420\u00a0s in <em>i</em>). If this is a gravitational lens, the non-detection of the lens suggests it is at a relatively high redshift (<em>z<sub>l</sub></em> \u2273 1).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100525 id=\"92100525\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-2>SDSS J0821+0735</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the spectra of the components (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) indicate that the quasar redshifts are almost same (\u0394<em>V</em> = 319\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), their SEDs appear to be slightly different. The emission line features have different profiles and the continuum shows differences in the slope. Some differences in the SEDs of lensed counterparts can be attributed to dust extinction in the lens galaxy (e.g. Falco et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) or microlensing. However, the UH88 imaging observation (1440\u00a0s in <em>I</em>) also failed to detect any lens between the quasar components.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100527 id=\"92100527\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-3>SDSS J0921+2854</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After we confirmed the lensing nature of this object, an archival search revealed that this lens was independently discovered by E. Ofek et\u00a0al., and was observed by the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> Cycle 20 programme GO-13001 although their results are unpublished. There are also X-ray and radio detections for this system, probably emanating from the lensed quasar.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100529 id=\"92100529\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-4>SDSS J0930+4614</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a quasar pair at the same redshift (\u0394<em>V</em> = 111\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) but with quite different SEDs (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The fainter component has broad absorption lines associated with Ly\u00a0\u03b1, Si\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines, while the brighter component has no broad absorption features. Given the markedly different SEDs, this is likely to be a physical quasar pair rather than a lens.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100531 id=\"92100531\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-5>SDSS J1043+4320</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a quasar pair with similar redshifts (\u0394<em>V</em> = 1778\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>). There are strong absorption lines in the C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines of both components, but the overall SED shapes appear to be different (see Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). It is important to conduct a deep imaging to search for a possible lens galaxy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100533 id=\"92100533\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-6>SDSS J1124+5710</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SEDs of this quasar pair appear similar but have slightly different redshifts (\u0394<em>V</em> = 496\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). There is no indication of a lens galaxy in our UH88 imaging (1440\u00a0s in <em>I</em>). Hence, we conclude that this is likely a binary quasar system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100535 id=\"92100535\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-7>SDSS J1309+5617</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the redshifts of the two components are almost identical (\u0394<em>V</em> = 169\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the significantly different shapes of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines mean that this system is likely to be a binary quasar system rather than a lens.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100537 id=\"92100537\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-8>SDSS J1405+1350</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SED of the fainter quasar has some similarity with the SED of the brighter quasar but the emission features have very low signal-to-noise ratios. The redshifts are not identical but imply that the quasars are probably physically associated (\u0394<em>V</em> = 1400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>). Additionally, the non-detection of a putative lens galaxy suggests this might be a binary quasar system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100539 id=\"92100539\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-9>SDSS J1452+4224</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> \u2248 4.8,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> the quasar redshift of this lens is one of the highest redshifts known and is comparable to the lens SDSS J0946+1835 (McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The total lensing magnification is predicted to be \u223c8 by our mass models in Section 4. The lens galaxy is quite visible in the spectrum and the image, and has one of the lowest measured lens redshift (<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.382) in our sample. Coincidentally, the lens galaxy of SDSS J0946+1835 is at a similar redshift but more massive given the wider image separations of the lensed quasars.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92100541 id=\"92100541\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-10>SDSS J2146\u22120047</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While the lensing nature of this object was confirmed by our imaging and spectroscopic follow-up observations, Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>) recently reported an independent discovery of this lens using Dark Energy Survey data. They tentatively assigned a lens redshift of <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.799 based on Mg\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and Fe\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption features in the quasar spectra. The absorption feature is also seen in the Subaru spectrum shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100543 id=\"92100543\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>MASS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We created mass models for the 13 spectroscopically confirmed lens systems with the modelling software, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The redshifts of the quasars and the lens galaxies were taken from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. For those systems with no lens redshifts, we adopted a fiducial value of <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.5 (\u223cpeak of the redshift distribution of typical lenses e.g. see Fig <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), as a lens redshift is required in the estimate of the velocity dispersion.</p>                        <a id=\"92100545\" scrollto-destination=\"92100545\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=QTO5I8V4qL2mEhJHOhqTz1e9lyf7InjHhJ32pnEGUzzEizZsdBAS6OWdgu4--ZQn4Tw1r2clsspk6k-E7Tq578wxaxgE5IsO3jfJQj09g2xnWB0gKHzU0OzLqdeSvp8eYzIFxsaa2SleIrdo4z9ldDSQXhhM-TIydp-sJJfT5AKKl~F6cQJRiq6FGeQb2S8hjafmMb5BEE9x-nEWzvT30YKllZ8nvFZt1WYtWBBB0k-M75l6H~lSyyt4e2dcizl3ZxG01uu3tnkKMdyr5LcxLnwIZaOqzUR1TBaTI5UgsU49uFlNvlghVmFywMNzkSZjS3bhDwv158phyYZulEeIbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100545/stv2813fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100545\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=YCBSrx17RLt7ZAYUUcjx1qvVpfz5-AzzD1gsHf0ttGET5QlHShGrRc0Q591Uue~NC60XkVjJqxF8zkwb~P1hpDvH6Bj6Vbnu4Pd5BbbmIAYiX5ftDH~Y44fZ3K~0cYzy9M2UQXaju0E1OSjJhuUv0Rke~SrpFOEWz00P37xXjmgRcQ602VgkuMY5iMli3pwqT79dwZJ6I2arE~5usYpszTLFfavUO7EhUO-oxuv-893DITqbms7OLq2-cjCcuuroTt7vBmwgENXNUMIPg52wZdGyF2enT9bVDlpwT4cfdXrssiCj72PddiuXa5WPx7Enz3R-lajtab-osPurynIrUQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100545&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/m_stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&amp;Signature=QTO5I8V4qL2mEhJHOhqTz1e9lyf7InjHhJ32pnEGUzzEizZsdBAS6OWdgu4--ZQn4Tw1r2clsspk6k-E7Tq578wxaxgE5IsO3jfJQj09g2xnWB0gKHzU0OzLqdeSvp8eYzIFxsaa2SleIrdo4z9ldDSQXhhM-TIydp-sJJfT5AKKl~F6cQJRiq6FGeQb2S8hjafmMb5BEE9x-nEWzvT30YKllZ8nvFZt1WYtWBBB0k-M75l6H~lSyyt4e2dcizl3ZxG01uu3tnkKMdyr5LcxLnwIZaOqzUR1TBaTI5UgsU49uFlNvlghVmFywMNzkSZjS3bhDwv158phyYZulEeIbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92100545/stv2813fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92100545\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/456/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2813/1/stv2813fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467135&Signature=YCBSrx17RLt7ZAYUUcjx1qvVpfz5-AzzD1gsHf0ttGET5QlHShGrRc0Q591Uue~NC60XkVjJqxF8zkwb~P1hpDvH6Bj6Vbnu4Pd5BbbmIAYiX5ftDH~Y44fZ3K~0cYzy9M2UQXaju0E1OSjJhuUv0Rke~SrpFOEWz00P37xXjmgRcQ602VgkuMY5iMli3pwqT79dwZJ6I2arE~5usYpszTLFfavUO7EhUO-oxuv-893DITqbms7OLq2-cjCcuuroTt7vBmwgENXNUMIPg52wZdGyF2enT9bVDlpwT4cfdXrssiCj72PddiuXa5WPx7Enz3R-lajtab-osPurynIrUQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92100545&ar=1070908&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2813fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the BQLS with the SQLS \u2018statistical\u2019 and \u2018all\u2019 samples. Owing to the smaller sample size of BQLS, a qualitative comparison is more meaningful. Each histogram is thus normalized and integrates to unity. Lenses with no known lens redshifts are excluded from the panel showing the redshift distributions. BQLS lenses are fainter and have smaller image separations. The quasar redshift distribution and the peak of the lens redshift distribution of the BQLS sample are similar to the SQLS \u2018all\u2019 sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assumed that the mass distribution of the lens galaxies is isothermal. More specifically, we either used the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) or ellipsoid (SIE) model for the lenses. Parameters such as the mass, ellipticity and the position angle (\u03b8<sub>e</sub>) of the lens model and the true (unlensed) position of the lensed quasar are allowed to be free. The positions and flux ratios<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> of the lensed quasar images served as constraints. We always begin with the SIS model and add further complexity such as adding more parameters only if the SIS results in a poor fit. The best-fitting parameters from the mass models are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92100547\" scrollto-destination=\"92100547\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting lens mass model parameters. The parameter \u03b8<sub>Ein</sub>, <em>e</em>, and \u03b8<sub>e</sub> denote the Einstein radius, ellipticity, and the position angle of the mass distribution, respectively. The numbers in bracket indicate which priors were used from the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>Ein</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em><span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0114+0722\u00a0</td><td>0.83\u00a0</td><td>0.42\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>This is an SIS model with priors on the lens position. Instead of the ellipticity and position angle, the last two columns list the best-fitting offset (in arcseconds) of the lens from one of the lensed quasars in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> direction, respectively. We use the standard Cartesian convention where <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are positive to the right and up, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100547\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting lens mass model parameters. .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n J0256+0153\u00a0</td><td>1.03\u00a0</td><td>0.74\u00a0</td><td>42\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0737+4825\u00a0</td><td>0.81\u00a0</td><td>0.25\u00a0</td><td>[\u221282]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0821+4542\u00a0</td><td>0.63\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>\u221221\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0921+2854\u00a0</td><td>0.96\u00a0</td><td>0.53\u00a0</td><td>28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>1.15\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>0.89\u00a0</td><td>[\u22120.553]\u00a0</td><td>[0.321]<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>0.84\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>52\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>1.03\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>0.87\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>1.15\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>1.14\u00a0</td><td>0.21\u00a0</td><td>[88]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>0.71\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>This is an SIS model with priors on the lens position. Instead of the ellipticity and position angle, the last two columns list the best-fitting offset (in arcseconds) of the lens from one of the lensed quasars in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> direction, respectively. We use the standard Cartesian convention where <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are positive to the right and up, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100547\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For SDSS J1330+3800, neither the SIS nor the SIE model could fit the constraints well. Hence, for this system, we used an SIS model with the lens galaxy position allowed to vary within the uncertainties from the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model. In a few other cases, we also used priors on the position angle of the lens based on the photometric models (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). In general, we could use the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> errors on the positions and fluxes of the lensed images but had to relax them<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> in a few cases in order to find a reasonable \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. The errors were relaxed up to \u223c0.15\u00a0arcsec and were always smaller than the pixel size. The best-fitting Einstein radii (or the velocity dispersions) of the BQLS lenses, which is a proxy for the mass of the lens galaxy, are similar to typical galaxy-scale lenses (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100549 id=\"92100549\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100550 id=\"92100550\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Properties of the BQLS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The basic properties of the 13 quasar lenses are summarized in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We also compare the image separation, magnitude, and redshift distributions of the newly discovered quasar lens systems with those of the SQLS sample in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In the redshift comparison, we exclude systems for which the lens redshifts are not known. There are two SQLS lens samples (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>): (i) \u2018all\u2019 \u2013 the entire lens sample which includes some heterogeneously selected lenses and (ii) \u2018stat\u2019 \u2013 this is a statistically well-defined sample with high completeness. The SQLS statistical lens sample is limited to the quasar redshift range of 0.6 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 2.2, <em>i</em>-band magnitude <em>i</em> &lt; 19.1, image separations 1\u2009arcsec &lt; \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 30\u2009arcsec, and flux ratios for doubles larger than 10<sup>\u22120.5</sup>, in order to accurately characterize the selection function.</p>                        <a id=\"92100552\" scrollto-destination=\"92100552\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the confirmed quasar lenses. The image separations \u0394\u03b8 are computed from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and the <em>i</em>-band PSF magnitudes are from the SDSS data base.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>2.381\u00a0</td><td>0.799\u00a0</td><td>1.39\u00a0</td><td>20.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b8(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" J0114+0722\u00a0</td><td>1.828\u00a0</td><td>0.408\u00a0</td><td>1.70\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0256+0153\u00a0</td><td>2.600\u00a0</td><td>0.603\u00a0</td><td>1.93\u00a0</td><td>20.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0737+4825\u00a0</td><td>2.892\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.54\u00a0</td><td>18.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0821+4542\u00a0</td><td>2.066\u00a0</td><td>0.349\u00a0</td><td>1.35\u00a0</td><td>18.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0921+2854\u00a0</td><td>1.410\u00a0</td><td>0.445\u00a0</td><td>1.91\u00a0</td><td>18.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1254+1857\u00a0</td><td>1.717\u00a0</td><td>0.555\u00a0</td><td>2.32\u00a0</td><td>19.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1330+3800\u00a0</td><td>2.254\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.44\u00a0</td><td>20.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1412+5204\u00a0</td><td>2.952\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.53\u00a0</td><td>19.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1442+4055\u00a0</td><td>2.575\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.13\u00a0</td><td>17.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1452+4224\u00a0</td><td>4.819\u00a0</td><td>0.382\u00a0</td><td>1.59\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1458\u22120202\u00a0</td><td>1.724\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.15\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1537+3014\u00a0</td><td>1.553\u00a0</td><td>0.490\u00a0</td><td>2.30\u00a0</td><td>19.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2146\u22120047\u00a0</td><td>2.381\u00a0</td><td>0.799\u00a0</td><td>1.39\u00a0</td><td>20.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100552\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the BOSS sample size is much smaller, we show normalized distributions to facilitate qualitative comparison of the properties of these samples. The image separation distribution suggests that the BOSS sample finds a larger fraction of small image separation (\u0394\u03b8 \u2272 2\u00a0arcsec) lenses compared to the SQLS sample. One likely reason for this difference is that we preferentially selected small-separation lens candidates for follow-up confirmation because larger separation quasar pairs are more likely to be physical pairs rather than real lenses (e.g. Kochanek, Falco &amp; Mu\u00f1oz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>). Another possibility may be fibre collisions. Large-separation lenses are produced by clusters of galaxies typically at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5, and therefore there are usually many member galaxies around the quasar images that are selected as Constant MASS (CMASS) galaxies for spectroscopy. This may reduce the chance of these quasar images being spectroscopically observed by BOSS. As mentioned earlier, this was indeed the case for SDSS J2222+2745 where none of the quasar images were observed by BOSS while spectra were taken of several nearby member galaxies of this cluster lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that 7 out of the 13 confirmed quasar lens systems are located at <em>z</em> &gt; 2.2. The fraction of high-redshift quasar lenses is not particularly high compared with the \u2018all\u2019 SQLS sample (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). This result may be partly explained by the fact that some of the new lens systems were originally targeted as CMASS galaxies rather than quasars because of the dominant lens galaxy component. Indeed, for many of these cases, the lens galaxies are visible in the SDSS spectra which then provide the lens redshifts for these systems (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Spectroscopic quasars selected in this manner are not necessarily high-redshift quasars. This also explains the peak of the lens redshift distribution at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> \u223c 0.5, which is close to the median redshift of the BOSS CMASS galaxy sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of the BQLS lenses are fainter because BOSS target selection selects fainter quasars. The BOSS DR12 quasar catalogue contains 25 previously known lenses, many found by the SQLS. About two-thirds of this sample are bright lens systems (<em>i</em> &lt; 18) with quasars at low redshifts (<em>z</em> &lt; 2.2). We excluded this known sample before the visual selection of the BQLS lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A subsample of the BOSS quasars are selected homogeneously and have a well-defined selection function which is called the CORE sample (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Lenses present in the CORE sample could be used to define a statistical sample for the BQLS provided the visual selection process is calibrated. However, only two out of the 13 confirmed lenses are in the CORE sample (using the boss_target1 flag for QSO_CORE_MAIN). It is unlikely that our visual inspection process is highly inefficient, so it is unlikely that we are missing a large number of true lenses. Therefore, even if we were to detect most of the true lenses, a statistically well-defined sample derived from this parent sample will still be probably too small for any statistical study. The \u2018point-source\u2019 requirement for the CORE sample is probably the cause of this low yield.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100557 id=\"92100557\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>Quad fraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the 13 confirmed quasar lenses are two-image quasar lens systems. At galaxy scales, we expect about 15\u201320\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the lenses to be quadruply imaged for the BOSS quasar lens sample with <em>i</em> \u2272 20 \u2212 21 (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) which means we should expect two or more quad lenses in our sample. There are several possible explanations for the lack of quad lenses in the BOSS quasar lens sample. First of all, the BOSS quasar target selection selects only point sources to increase its efficiency (Ross et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), whereas small-separation quad lens systems are often classified as extended sources in the SDSS (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Indeed, all the four small-separation (\u0394\u03b8 &lt; 2\u00a0arcsec) quad lenses discovered in the SQLS (see Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) are found to be classified as extended sources in the SDSS data set. In addition, the visual inspection method might be biased against selecting quad lenses because the quads appear to have odd morphology. And, spectroscopic follow-up observations might be biased because single long-slit mode is used to target the double quasar candidate images along with the candidate lens galaxy for confirmation. Therefore, it is of great interest to apply more sophisticated algorithms (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to the quasars in BOSS to search for quad lenses that are missing in the current lens sample.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92100559 id=\"92100559\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>Quasar pairs</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our follow-up spectroscopy identified an additional 11 quasar pairs with small angular separations of \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 3\u00a0arcsec (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for a summary). We expect most of these to be either projected pairs or binary quasars, based on their different SEDs and the lack of an obvious lens. Among the 11 quasar pairs, 7 pairs have the velocity difference \u0394<em>V</em> smaller than 2000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and therefore satisfy the criterion of physical binaries used in Hennawi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>). The velocity difference may also be useful for distinguishing binary quasars from lensed quasars. We find that the typical \u0394<em>V</em> of the confirmed lenses measured from our follow-up spectra is &lt;40 and \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in a few cases, which can be regarded as a typical error on our velocity difference measurements. From Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we find that most of the quasar pairs have velocity differences significantly larger than those of the confirmed lenses, indicating that they are less likely to be lensed images of a single source but rather are physically associated distinct quasars.</p>                        <a id=\"92100561\" scrollto-destination=\"92100561\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl7\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl7\" data-id=\"tbl7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of confirmed quasar pairs. See Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for the RA and Dec. of the brighter quasar image (A). The positions and the <em>i</em>-band magnitudes in this table are from the SDSS data base except for J0818+0601 where we used the astrometrically calibrated SOAR images.</p></div> </div><div J1548+2830\u00a0</td><td>15:48:50.776\u00a0</td><td>+28:30:12.714\u00a0</td><td>3.208\u00a0</td><td>1.487\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>20.8\u00a0</td><td>20.9\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J2245+2548\u00a0</td><td>22:45:55.801\u00a0</td><td>+25:48:33.548\u00a0</td><td>2.995\u00a0</td><td>2.178\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td><td>20.4\u00a0</td><td>20.7\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92100561\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In general, there are still only a small number of quasar pairs known (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and our sample adds significantly to the existing pair samples. For comparison, the SQLS only identified eight binary quasars with \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 3\u00a0arcsec (see Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, for a compilation), which is comparable to the number of new binary quasars from the BQLS. The small-separation binary quasars have been used to study the very small scale clustering of quasars to discuss the possible role of mergers in enhancing quasar activities (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>; Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Shen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kayo &amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Projected quasar pairs are also useful for studying the distribution of absorbers around quasars (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100563 id=\"92100563\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the initial results from BQLS, a systematic search for lensed quasars in the SDSS-III/BOSS data. We applied the same technique that we used for finding lensed quasars in the SDSS DR7 (SQLS). Here, we report the discovery of 13 confirmed quasar lenses. In addition, we present the discovery of 11 quasar pairs, some of which may consist of physical binaries. This subsample may still contain a few unrecognized lenses. The sample of new lenses includes one of the highest redshift lensed quasar (SDSS J1452+4224, <em>z</em> \u2248 4.8) found to date. SDSS J1442+4055 was also discovered independently by Sergeyev et\u00a0al. 2015 (submitted to MNRAS, private communication from Luis J. Goicoechea). All the confirmed lenses from the BQLS have only two images. The lack of quad lenses is probably because BOSS only selects point-like quasars. We note that our follow-up observations are still incomplete with an additional \u223c50 good lens candidates that need verification. However, this sample is likely to have fewer real lenses since we conducted the follow-up observations of the most promising candidates first.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to the SQLS, the selection function of the BQLS sample is complicated owing to the complex selection of the initial BOSS quasar targets. In addition to the incomplete follow-up observations, a complex selection function prevents us from using the BQLS sample for statistical studies of either the lens population or cosmology (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The CORE sample from BOSS, which is a uniform and well-defined quasar sample could be used to produce a statistical BQLS sample, yielded only two lenses. This is probably because the quasars are required to be point-like in the CORE sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A qualitative comparison of the initial BQLS sample with the SQLS shows that BQLS lenses are somewhat fainter and have smaller image separations, presumably due to the BOSS selection criteria. Furthermore, the BQLS and SQLS lensed quasars have similar redshift distributions in spite of the higher redshift selection used for BOSS quasars. This is because many of the lenses in our sample were photometrically identified as galaxies before they were spectroscopically confirmed by BOSS to be quasars. In addition, about half of the lensed quasars have redshifts lower than the quasar redshift range targeted by BOSS. These lenses would have been missed in the absence of BOSS CMASS galaxy spectroscopy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This study provides useful guidance for ongoing quasar lens surveys in Hyper Suprime-Cam<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> and Dark Energy Survey (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) in which even fainter quasar lenses will be discovered.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The work of MO and AM was supported in part by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. This work was also supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research from the JSPS (26800093 and 24740171). AM would like to thank S. More and J. Silverman for useful suggestions. AM acknowledges the support of the Japan Society for Promotion of Science (JSPS) fellowship. AMM acknowledges the support of NSF grant AST-1211146. The authors would like to thank the anonymous referee for useful suggestions that improved the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, and the US Department of Energy Office of Science. The SDSS-III web site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss3.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss3.org/</a>. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, Harvard University, the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, the Michigan State/Notre Dame/JINA Participation Group, Johns Hopkins University, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics, Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, New Mexico State University, New York University, Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, University of Portsmouth, Princeton University, the Spanish Participation Group, University of Tokyo, University of Utah, Vanderbilt University, University of Virginia, University of Washington, and Yale University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based in part on data collected at Subaru Telescope, which is operated by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan. Use of the UH 2.2-m telescope for the observations is supported by NAOJ. Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. A part of this work is based on observations obtained at the MDM Observatory, operated by Dartmouth College, Columbia University, Ohio State University, Ohio University, and the University of Michigan. Based on observations obtained at the SOAR telescope, which is a joint project of the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia, e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (MCTI) da Rep\u00fablica Federativa do Brasil, the US National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), and Michigan State University (MSU).</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> is distributed by the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, which are operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Redshifts from Ly\u00a0\u03b1 at such high redshifts are strongly affected by the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 forest (McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Therefore, we give fewer significant digits on the redshift estimate.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The flux ratios are often known to be affected by dust, substructure, intrinsic quasar variability and microlensing. Thus, a simple globally smooth models such as the ones tested here may fail to fit the flux ratios and cannot necessarily be used to rule out the lens hypothesis.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This is reasonable because the errors from <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> are known to be an underestimate (e.g. Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.naoj.org/Projects/HSC/surveyplan.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.naoj.org/Projects/HSC/surveyplan.html</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92100578 id=\"92100578\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Agnello</div>\r\n <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Kelly</div>\r\n <div class=\"given-names\">B. Astrof\u00edsica, E-38206 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain), AR(The University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA; The Enrico Fermi Institute, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "456", "publication_year": "2016/02/1", "start_page": "1595", "end_page": "1606", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: statistical", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016MNRAS.456.1595M", "abstract": "We report the discovery of 13 confirmed two-image quasar lenses from a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in the SDSS-III Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS). We adopted a methodology similar to that used in the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS). In addition to the confirmed lenses, we report 11 quasar pairs with small angular separations ( \u2272 2 arcsec) confirmed from our spectroscopy, which are either projected pairs, physical binaries, or possibly quasar lens systems whose lens galaxies have not yet been detected. The newly discovered quasar lens system, SDSS J1452+4224 at z<SUB>s</SUB> \u2248 4.8 is one of the highest redshift multiply imaged quasars found to date. Furthermore, we have over 50 good lens candidates yet to be followed up. Owing to the heterogeneous selection of BOSS quasars, the lens sample presented here does not have a well-defined selection function.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stv2813", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1509.07917", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
